title: TEST MOBILE
description: Which site are users more engaged on a dedicated mobile site or a mobile-responsive site? Test to find out.

title: BE RESPONSIVE
description: Between phones, tablets, PCs, and TVs, there are plenty of ways for users to access the web. Consider a responsive designed based on the device your customers are using.

title: DESIGN FOR THE FIRST-TIME USER
description: Although first-time users won’t have any data to display, make sure they still see an attractive interface. Avoid designing only for your heavy users.

title: ADD REASSURANCES
description: Overcome typical buyer objections by adding reassurances (no risk, cancel any time, 100% guaranteed, etc.).

title: CONSIDER MOBILE USERS
description: The number of mobile users continues to grow. Optimize for them so they’ll be less likely to leave your site for a competitor.

title: USE SOCIAL PROOF
description: Have over 1,000 users? Don’t be shy, social proof is powerful. Display that information online.

title: CHANGE THE MAIN VALUE PROPOSITION
description: Ease-of-use may be more appealing to some users, whereas quality of materials may increase sales with others. Experiment with your main value proposition to see which gets better results.

title: APPEAL TO THE HEAD (OR HEART!)
description: For some products and services, an intellectual appeal works better than an emotional one (and vice versa). Try switching up your appeals to see which works best.

title: CREATE URGENCY
description: Urgency is a very effective method for increasing sales. Add copy explaining why someone must act now--be honest so you’re not sacrificing credibility in the process.

title: WORK THE “WHY”
description: What’s most persuasive with consumers? Change the copy explaining “why” they need your solution and find out.

title: ELICIT CURIOSITY
description: Teasers are a great way to get people to read your copy in its entirety. Drop hooks and hints that compel readers to learn more.

title: PACK A POWERFUL STORY
description: Stories and reviews are excellent tactics to persuade reluctant customers to buy.

title: EMPHASIZE SCARCITY
description: Scarcity works. If you only have 2 books, sweaters, or software packages left in stock, say so.

title: BE BIG ON BENEFITS
description: People don’t buy features, they buy benefits. Rather than merely listing specs (this printer prints 30 pages/minute), focus on the benefit to the consumer (“Never wait again for pages to print!)

title: GO GLOBAL
description: Do you have users regularly accessing your site from other parts of the world? Try using language-specific content based on user locations.

title: REPETITION WORKS
description: Got a long page? Repeat your CTA multiple times to make sure customers get the message.

title: TELL A STORY
description: Rather than merely listing them, try showcasing your product with a story.

title: STARS WORK
description: Have you received amazing feedback on your products? Don’t be shy--include star ratings on the product page.

title: SHOW YOUR DELIVERABLES
description: Professional photos of your deliverables can boost sales. Add them and see for yourself.

title: TEASE WITH YOUR HEADLINE
description: A headline that hints at a mystery--rather than clearly divulging information--makes for a great hook.

title: WRITE A LETTER
description: Sales letters can be very effective at earning conversions. While they certainly don’t work for every market, you may want to experiment with one to see how it impacts sales.

title: CHANGE IT UP
description: Rather than emphasizing the same benefit you always do in your headline, pick a new benefit and see how consumers respond.

title: BUILD TRUST
description: Adding trust seals will help overcome buyer objections.

title: OVERHAUL IT
description: Try redesigning your mobile home page, then test the new version against your old one.

title: TARGET YOUR PROSPECT
description: Rather than targeting everyone, identify in your headline exactly who your solution’s for.

title: PHONE IT IN
description: There are still plenty of people who don’t like submitting orders online. If someone starts to leave your site, consider a pop-up box suggesting they call to place their order instead.

title: TEST A CONVERSION PATH
description: If you have multiple different target audiences (i.e. Current College Students, Prospective Students, Parents), try showing pages that are unique to each group.

title: ANCHOR IT
description: People love getting a deal. Try anchoring your price by showing 2 prices. For instance, you could show a suggested retail price of $199, cross it out, and next to it, display an actual price of $99.

title: GIVE IT AWAY
description: “Free” is a compelling word. Use it in your headline and find out just how powerful it is!

title: ADD PAYMENT OPTIONS
description: Rather than limiting payment options, try accepting PayPal, Bitcoin, etc.

title: TEST YOUR DEALS
description: Which generates more sales--free shipping or a percentage off? Test and find out.

title: ALLOW TRIALS
description: Consumers are reluctant to purchase things they’re not sure they’ll enjoy using. A trial membership gives them the opportunity to see for themselves how much they’ll love your product.

title: GIVE FREE SAMPLES
description: Free samples do 2 things: (1) they increase the likelihood of a purchase and (2) they introduce customers to new products they might then buy in the future.

title: PLAY NICE WITH OTHERS
description: Allow affiliates to sell products on your website. Not only will you make more money, but you’ll also gain valuable insights by studying their conversion rates.

title: TEST YOUR REASSURANCES
description: Which is more effective--a free trial or a money-back guarantee? And what happens if you offer both?

title: TEST VARIOUS PRICE POINTS
description: How do people react when your product is $20? $25? $30? Play with various price points to determine your most profitable price.

title: GET SPECIFIC (OR NOT)
description: Test a broad offer against an offer segmented for a specific audience.

title: OFFER LIVE CHAT
description: In a recent Forrester Research study, 44% of customers said they want live chat assistance when they’re making a purchase. Add it and watch your conversions increase.

title: GET INTO THE SPIRIT
description: People tend to have more free time to shop around the holidays. Take advantage of that by testing special holiday offers and seasonal discounts.

title: ANTICIPATE INTENT
description: Does moving a mouse to a submenu cause the user to scroll over the main menu, making the submenu disappear? Anticipate scenarios like these so you can prevent them.

title: SEGMENT CUSTOMERS
description: Segment offers by testing those designed for current customers vs. those designed for non-customers..

title: OPTIMIZE CODE
description: Optimized code decreases page loading times, minimizing the likelihood of someone leaving your site.

title: PROMOTE CREDIBILITY
description: One under-utilized resource for testimonials is the media. Media testimonials can be particularly helpful if your site is brand-new. Try offering free products to the media in exchange for reviews or feedback.

title: TO GATE OR NOT TO GATE?
description: That is the question. Seriously, try testing conversion rates of gated content (content that users can’t access until they fill out a form) vs. ungated content.

title: ADDRESS UNCERTAINTIES
description: There are a number of concerns that prevent buyers from purchasing. These concerns include things like warranty length, return policy, and shipping speed. Try addressing these uncertainties on your product pages, rather than making users hunt for the information.

title: ISOLATE A BENEFIT
description: Rather than elaborating on every single benefit your solution provides, try picking one and really emphasizing its importance.

title: REWARD CUSTOMERS
description: Loyalty points and customer levels can compel customers to spend more.

title: ALTER PRODUCT DESCRIPTION COPY
description: Is your product description copy as effective as it could be? Try different versions to see what works best.

title: VARY SELLING TACTICS
description: Some products are better suited to hard sells than others. Test soft sell appeals versus hard sell appeals to see which works best.

title: CREATE CREDIBILITY
description: Don’t expect customers to be impressed with fluff copy. Instead, try adding facts and figures that prove your claims.

title: MAKE A RECOMMENDATION
description: Is there a complimentary product that would go well with something your customer already has in his cart? Recommend it!

title: TEST URGENCY
description: Some urgent appeals may be more successful than others. Try testing various appeals (i.e. a countdown clock vs. “Sale ends Sunday at midnight” text) to see which is most compelling to customers.

title: CUT THE COPY (OR VICE VERSA)
description: What works best--long or short copy? It depends. Test both and see which is most effective with your audience.

title: MOVE YOUR CTA
description: Your CTA’s location could be promoting--or preventing--sales. Experiment to see what works best.

title: HYPER-FOCUS ON YOUR CTA
description: By minimizing links on the page, you can focus customers’ attention on your CTA.

title: MINIMIZE CHOICE
description: It would seem like the more choice you offer to consumers, the more likely they’d be to buy. Not so. Too many choices can overwhelm people, causing them to lead the page.

title: PLAY WITH LINKS
description: How many links do you need on your page? Test lots of links vs. few links to find out.

title: CHANGE YOUR FOCUS
description: Is there a page where you’re only featuring 1 product? Try featuring multiple products. Likewise, replace multiple products with just 1 product and see what happens.

title: GET REAL
description: Rather than using stock photos and bogus reviews, use photos of real people and genuine reviews. Authenticity works!

title: EXPERIMENT WITH FORM LAYOUT
description: If you’re using a sign-up form on your e-commerce pages, test a horizontal layout against a vertical layout.

title: VARY PRODUCT IMAGES
description: Does Photo A of your product generate more sales than Photo B of your product?

title: DITCH RELATED PRODUCTS
description: When consumers are close to making a purchase, tempting them with related items can be distracting. Unfortunately, that means they might never get around to buying. Try removing related products and analyzing the impact on conversions.

title: READY, SET, GO!
description: In some industries, it’s useful to begin the order form on the actual product page. Try doing this for just 1 or 2 of your products and see how this change affects conversions.

title: USE VIDEO
description: Many consumers would rather watch a video than read copy. Try adding one to pages where it makes sense.

title: PLAY IN THE BACKGROUND
description: Try testing a blank background against a photo background page.

title: DON’T HIDE
description: A lot of businesses bury their customer service numbers. Try moving it above the fold so visitors can easily get help.

title: PREVENT SHOPPING
description: Prevent might be a strong word. You may, however, consider making it more difficult. It’s not uncommon for users to get distracted while shopping and ironically, fail to actually complete a purchase they were considering. Rather than displaying a “Continue Shopping” button after someone adds to their cart, just show your “Checkout” button and the top navigation.

title: OFFER AMAZON
description: Amazon has plenty of fans. If someone fills their cart on your site and then tries to navigate away, consider a pop-up box directing them to Amazon to complete their purchase.

title: PRESENT A GIFT
description: Rather than closing a sale right away, try offering your customer a gift.

title: TRIAL LENGTH SHOWDOWN
description: Which works best--a 14-day trial or a 30-day trial? Surprisingly, one company found that shorter trials were more effective. Test to see if that holds true for your company.

title: TRY SOMETHING UNEXPECTED
description: Do you typically offer the same deals and discounts over and over again? Brainstorm and offer something unexpected next time.

title: EXPERIMENT WITH SHOPPING LINKS
description: Rather than displaying top navigation when someone adds something to a shopping cart, remove it altogether and just use a “Continue Shopping” link.

title: EASE INTO COMMITMENT
description: Rather than asking people to fork over a large annual fee, ask for a smaller monthly commitment.

title: SORT ON $$$
description: If you aren’t already, try presenting items with pricing as your default sort option. You can test Highest to Lowest Price, Lowest to Highest Price, or both.

title: REACH OUT
description: Did someone abandon a full shopping cart? Remind them to complete their purchase by sending a follow-up email. For additional testing, try altering the timing and content of the email.

title: TRY A MOST POPULAR SORT
description: Consumers tend to trust their peers when it comes to purchases. Take advantage of that by setting your default sort to show your most popular items first.

title: COLLECT SETS
description: People enjoy collecting. Rather than having them collect individual items like leadership awards, have them collect 3 awards to earn a leadership badge.

title: ALLOW DIRECT MANIPULATION
description: Rather than making users jump through a series of hoops to manipulate data, allow them to manipulate text fields directly.

title: TRY DISCRETION
description: Most websites present choices when customers are about to complete purchases: sign in, create an account, or check out as a guest. Try displaying only your sign in fields. You can reveal guest/account creation fields later if users click on those links.

title: TRY TABLET OPTIMIZATION
description: Online store Shirtinator used this tactic to great success. Initially, the company only offered sites for desktop and mobile users. Tablet users were directed to the mobile site. After optimizing their desktop site for tablet users, they began redirecting those users to the desktop site--doing so led to a whopping 72% increase in revenue! Could it do the same for you?

title: USE GENTLE PROMPTS
description: Pop-up windows can be annoying. Try using inline or slide-out prompts that get the message across without being distracting.

title: USE RECOGNITION
description: Recognition is easier than recall. Avoid asking users to recall specifics like their favorite book. Instead, offer them a list to choose from.

title: TO TURN A PAGE OR NOT?
description: Do some testing to determine whether your customers prefer scrolling down a page to turning the page.

title: TRY POP-UPS
description: Wanna get your customers to sign up for your email list? A pop-up may be the answer.

title: PERFORM USEFUL CALCULATIONS
description: Rather than asking people to do math, calculate things for your users (for example, displaying a time stamp of 4 minutes ago, instead of 9/27/2018 4:34PM).

title: OFFER A SURVEY
description: By asking customers to participate in a brief survey, you can learn valuable information about their buying habits.

title: ADD FAQs
description: A FAQs page presents an ideal opportunity to overcome typical buyer objections. Rather than making customers hunt for information about your return policy or shipping terms, try addressing these topics on an FAQs page.

title: DON’T LEAVE SALES TO CHANCE
description: Imagine you’re a customer visiting a product page on your website. What objections would you have about that product? Is it too expensive? Would you be skeptical of its quality? Does it look difficult to use? The objections you have are the same ones your customers are likely to have. Rather than hoping they’ll buy despite those objections, create copy that effectively addresses them.

title: PROMPT THE NEXT ACTION
description: Post-purchase, try prompting customers’ next action by suggesting they post about their purchase on Facebook or check out the new items you have in stock.

title: TRY A NEW WRITING PERSPECTIVE
description: Rather than writing in a he/she/they perspective, see what impact using “you” has on sales.

title: RENAME YOUR SOLUTION
description: While you shouldn’t judge a book by its cover, people do so anyways. Try renaming your product to see how customers react.

title: TRY VARIOUS REVIEW SITES
description: Do customers value some types of reviews more than others? Try testing testimonials, Yelp reviews, and/or ResellerRatings against each other and see.

title: APPEAL TO RETURNING CUSTOMERS
description: Rather than showing returning customers the same content everyone else sees, why not display content designed to appeal to their interests?

title: BUILD ENGAGEMENT
description: People find quizzes and polls intriguing. Use them periodically to test engagement.

title: USE A SHIPPING SHOUT-OUT
description: With the advent of the Internet, it’s not unusual to have global customers. Rather than making international customers visit your FAQs page to learn whether you ship to their location, offer that information in your header or product pages.

title: GO BIG WITH BULLETS
description: People skim paragraphs. Turn paragraphs into bullet points to very quickly communicate your main points.

title: DON’T BEAT AROUND THE BUSH
description: Rather than being hesitant (“If you’re interested...”), use direct language (“Buy It Now.”)

title: VARY APPEAL
description: Which works best--a text CTA or an icon CTA? Try them both.

title: TRY BENEFIT BUTTONS
description: Instead of focusing on the task at hand (“Sign Up Now”), try a benefit button (“Save Money Now”).

title: CREATE COLOR CONTRAST
description: Make your CTAs stand out more by contrasting their color with the other items on the page.

title: USE CTAS CREATIVELY
description: Using product images? Try putting a CTA inside the image.

title: INCREASE YOUR CTAS
description: What happens when you test a single CTA on a page vs. multiple CTAs on a page?

title: SWITCH IT UP (YOUR CTA, THAT IS)
description: The order of the links and CTA on your page could be affecting sales. Try switching them up for maximum impact.

title: JUST SAY CHEESE
description: If you have a signup page on your website that lacks a photo, try adding one. This tactic has been shown to improve conversions.

title: SHOW OFF YOUR ASSETS
description: There’s a ton of competition on the Internet. With that in mind, why should site visitors purchase from you, rather than a competitor? Once you’ve answered that question, use the information to create a site-wide benefits bar directly below your header.

title: GRAB ATTENTION
description: By inserting directional arrows and irregular shapes, you can control the direction of consumers’ gaze.

title: SHOW YOUR FANS
description: Customer photos next to testimonials can add a nice touch--just be sure to get permission first!

title: ALTER YOUR ALGORITHM
description: Many websites use a related products section to display items similar to those a customer has already expressed interest in. If your website uses this section, try altering the algorithm and testing.

title: EMPHASIZE THE RIGHT STUFF
description: Use your home page to display your most popular items or those with the highest profit margins.

title: ELIMINATE CONFUSION
description: Comparing multiple products? Don’t get too complex. Instead, use an easy-to-read table.

title: SWITCH UP YOUR HOME PAGE
description: Your home page is the ideal place to display photos of customers using your products.

title: TRY GROUPING
description: Make things easier for your customers by grouping related items. Rather than putting all women’s shirts in one category, for example, try grouping them by type (V-neck, tee, etc.)

title: DON’T SCATTER ATTENTION
description: Lots of boxes, borders, and graphics can be overly confusing. If you have an excess of them, try cutting the clutter.

title: USE ICON LABELS
description: Rather than just using a pencil or trash can to signify edits and deletes, spell out exactly what those icons mean.

title: USE THE PRODUCT (OR DON’T)
description: What works best--photos of people using your product or an image of just the product itself? Test and find out.

title: REPLACE IMAGES
description: Try swapping some of the images on your website for videos to see how people respond.

title: CHANGE YOUR PHOTOS
description: Using stock photos? Try photos of real people instead.

title: CHECK ALL ANGLES
description: Access your website from different browsers and various screen resolutions to see what your customers are seeing.

title: SWAP A GUARANTEE FOR TRUST
description: A watch company replaced its price guarantee with a trust symbol and saw conversions increase by 107%. While this tactic may not have such a huge impact on every retailer, it’s worth testing to find out.

title: HELP USERS VISUALIZE
description: Rather than just showing your product or people using it, try showing photos of the outcome users will experience if they buy your product. For example, a home listings site found that by changing their existing photo to one of someone standing next to a “Sold” sign, signups increased by 89%.

title: AIM FOR CLARITY
description: Rather than making elements on the page appear subtly different, eliminate ambiguity by clearly highlighting the differences between them.

title: GET STRONG
description: Strong adverbs/adjectives in the headline can make a big impact. Try words like remarkable, sensational, startling, quick, easy, etc.

title: HIERARCHY HELPS
description: Visual hierarchy helps the reader have a clear picture of what’s most important on a page.

title: USE A SUBHEADER
description: Sometimes a headline just isn’t enough. Try adding a subheader to further sway consumers.

title: TALK LOSS
description: People don’t like to lose. Rather than emphasizing benefit (“do this to gain money”), speak to their fears (“stop losing money”).

title: TRY PERCENTAGES
description: Putting a percentage in a headline is an effective way to attract attention.

title: USE A POWER WORD
description: The 5 most persuasive words in the English language are: You, Free, Because, Instantly, and New. Use these (or other copywriting power words) in your headlines for maximum impact.

title: TRACK BUYING HABITS
description: Wanna learn more about how your target audience shops? Consider allowing users to create a free account on your site so you can track their purchasing behaviors.

title: ELIMINATE GUESSING
description: Do customers have to hunt for your FAQs and Buying Guides? If so, put them above the fold. Customers who have to work too hard will head to a more user-friendly site.

title: BROADEN YOUR APPEAL
description: Appeal to those who are price-sensitive and those who aren’t by offeringstandard and premium versions.

title: REMOVE DROP-DOWNS
description: Some users find drop-down menus irritating. Try removing them and putting your links on well-designed product category pages, particularly if you have an older target audience.

title: DON’T LOSE AT HIDE-AND-SEEK
description: Promo code fields cause users to search the web, seeking out the best deal they can find. Unfortunately, they don’t always return. Try hiding your promo code field instead. You can accomplish that by using a small promo code link that doesn’t display a data field until it’s clicked.

title: ELIMINATE BUYER OBJECTION
description: A major reason people hesitate from buying online is because returns can be a hassle. If you’ve made returns simple--or better yet, free--don’t be shy. State this upfront on your site.

title: MAKE IT OBVIOUS
description: Is your price buried below the fold? Move it up higher on the page and test the results.

title: USE PRICE ILLUSIONS
description: Price illusions increase the perception of value. For instance, if you’re selling a subscription box, you may want to remind customers they’re getting each item in the box for just X dollars.

title: CREATE COMBOS
description: By packaging individual items into combinations, you can increase sales of complementary items.

title: CREATE A PROMOTIONS SECTION
description: Approximately 60% of online shoppers say they’re looking for a site section that contains deals and specials. Make it easy for them to find discounts by adding one to your website.

title: GUARANTEE IT
description: Build consumer trust by offering a price match guarantee on your website.

title: GET GENEROUS
description: A contest or a prize draw is a great way to increase site engagement while collecting email addresses.

title: USE INLINE VALIDATION
description: Don’t make users wait until they’ve clicked submit before showing data errors. Instead, use inline validation so they can make corrections immediately.

title: MAKE COMPARISONS EASY
description: Do you have a link on your site allowing users to compare similar items? If so, consider adding hover text over your comparison link, explaining how the compare features works (i.e. select up to 3 items to compare).

title: SHOWCASE NEW ITEMS
description: Wanna generate buzz about your newest products? Change your default sort to display them first.

title: SIMPLIFY SHIPPING
description: Rather than making users type in their shipping address, allow them to check a box indicating their shipping and billing addresses are the same.

title: SQUEEZE FUNCTIONS INTO 1 CONTROL
description: To minimize the number of controls on the screen, try combining functionality. For example, you could combine a search field with filtering functionality. Then when your user types the letter “M,” he would only be shown items beginning with M.

title: OFFER EASY REDOS
description: Make redos simple. For instance, if a user goes to watch a video on your site and it doesn’t load correctly, display a link he can click on to reload it.

title: PROVIDE FEEDBACK
description: When users submit a request or email, don’t leave them hanging. Let them know when and how they can expect to hear back from you.

title: SIMPLIFY SEARCH
description: As users are typing in the search field, populate it with a list of results.

title: SHOW STATUS
description: Don’t make users guess. Rather than merely showing invoices, for example, show the user the status of the invoice (paid, due xx/xx/xxxx, etc.)

title: MINIMIZE CERTAIN FUNCTIONALITY
description: Regular users of your site tend to use the same functionality repeatedly. Rather than continually showing them functions they’re unlikely to use, display items that are more relevant.

title: ALLOW EASY UNDOS
description: Instead of prompting for confirmation (“Are you sure you want to make this change?” try “Your change has been saved, click here if you want to undo it.”)

title: BE PERSISTENT
description: Comparison shopping on the Internet is a given. Many customers will fill up a shopping cart, check a few other websites, and then return later to make their purchase. Rather than letting them come back to empty carts, use a persistent cookie to maintain carts’ contents.

title: WHAT’S THE TEMPERATURE?
description: Some companies personalize user experiences based on weather targeting. For instance, clothing retailers might alter their home page to show images of people wearing scarves on cold days, shorts on sunny days, etc.

title: DITCH FLASH
description: Flash is outdated and doesn’t work on all devices. If you’re using a Flash banner, try replacing it with a JavaScript banner instead.

title: REFER-A-FRIEND IS YOUR FRIEND
description: Word-of-mouth can be extremely influential. If you’re not doing so already, make it easy for site visitors to refer a friend to your site.

title: OPT FOR PERSONALIZATION
description: Refer-A-Friend messages that use canned text sound artificial and unconvincing. Allow customers to add a personal message to Refer-A-Friend text for maximum impact.

title: OPT TO CHANGE JUST 1 BULLET
description: An e-book author changed just 1 bullet of his promotional copy and saw conversions increase by 18.59%. Could tweaking a bullet significantly increase your conversions? Test and find out.

title: ENGAGE GRADUALLY
description: People can be reluctant to commit. Rather than asking them to create an account to use your scrapbook creation tool, for example, start small by asking them to select its color first.

title: OFFER CHOICE
description: Nobody likes being told what to do. Use reverse psychology by reaffirming freedom (“It’s your choice, you’re free to ignore this offer.”)

title: STRIKE A CONVERSATION
description: Dry, textbook-like copy is boring. Try appealing to your customer in the same way you’d talk to a friend.

title: HUMOR HELPS
description: People are more likely to read copy if it’s interesting. Try injecting humor into your copy, rather than being overly serious.

title: CHANGE NAVIGATION TITLES
description: Have your product offerings changed significantly since your website first went live? Are your product categories outdated? Perhaps your navigation titles need an overhaul. Test the impact of using different titles.

title: DON’T APPEAR NOSY
description: You walk a fine line in ecommerce. There’s plenty of information you need to complete an order, but ask for too much, and it comes off as being intrusive. If there’s information you need, offer reassurance by explaining why you need it. For instance, you might try including a link to your privacy policy beneath your email newsletter sign-up form.

title: CUT THE COPY
description: Try being very concise with your copy--use shorter sentences and fewer paragraphs, then test their impact.

title: GO BIG OR GO HOME
description: Why not try making your CTA button larger?

title: GET PERSONAL
description: Generic copy is dull. Inject personality into your copy by introducing yourself, your place of business, or the origin of the product itself.

title: CUT CLUTTER
description: Increase the empty space around your CTA to make it stand out.

title: ENABLE HOVERING
description: Will a rollover effect (like a change in color, lighting, saturation, or even the image itself) cause more users to click on your CTA? Try it and see.

title: USE CUES
description: Visual cues like arrows can draw attention to your CTA.

title: ADD LIFESTYLE IMAGES
description: Lifestyle images can be very compelling. Try adding one or more to the description section of your product pages.

title: TARGET YOUR DEMOGRAPHIC
description: Rather than just using a “Call Us” link, display the name and photo of your call center rep. For best results, choose someone who is similar to your demographic.

title: DON’T GET CRAZY
description: While it’s fine to design creative web pages, don’t go nuts. Adhere to convention rather than confusing your customers. For instance, the trash icon is synonymous with deletion. Don’t replace it with an image that’s only relevant to you. People appreciate predictability when it comes to common functionality.

title: ADD IMAGE CAPTIONS
description: Try captioning your images. If you want, you can even put your CTA within the captions and test how often it’s clicked.

title: JAZZ IT UP
description: Adding quotes and other stylistic changes to your testimonials will make customers more likely to read your glowing reviews.

title: EXPLAIN YOURSELF
description: Some potential customers like to know as much as possible about a company before doing business with it. Try adding some “About Us” content to your home page. If that type of content already exists on the home page, remove it and see what happens.

title: USE CONSISTENCY
description: People appreciate a sense of familiarity. Aim for consistency on all elements of your web page--colors, directions, behaviors, positions, sizes, shapes, labels, and language.

title: PLAY WITH ADS
description: Displaying ads on your site? Test their sizes, shapes, and positions.

title: DO SOME DIGGING
description: Are there certain items people search for on your website again and again? Increase their prominence by featuring them on your home page or by changing your navigation.

title: SHOW OFF YOUR STUFF
description: Relocate those ratings and reviews so they’re closer to products’ prices.

title: BUILD A BRIDGE
description: Bridge the gap between your headline and body copy by increasing the font size of your first paragraph.

title: EXPERIMENT WITH LAYOUT
description: If you’re using multiple columns, try a single column layout--or vice versa--to see which works best.

title: USE AD BANNERS
description: Putting ad banners on each of your content pages may increase engagement and conversions. Test and see.

title: REMOVE THE SLIDER
description: Rather than a rotating carousel of images, get rid of the slider and test the impact.

title: ZOOM IT
description: Try giving users the option to zoom in on product photos--details can make all the difference.

title: DEMOTE DROP-DOWNS
description: Lengthy drop-down lists can overwhelm users. Consider replacing them with a text field auto-suggest feature.

title: DON’T BE (TOO MUCH OF) A HERO
description: Hero images are large banner images that span the width of the home page. Rather than letting a hero hog valuable home page space, why not reduce it to two-thirds the width of your page?

title: PERFORM MATH WITH RELATED PRODUCTS
description: Not sure how many related products you should display? Try adding and subtracting products to find your ideal number.

title: SHOW PRODUCTS IN RANGE
description: Rather than showing consumers related products in a vast price range, try showing products similar in price.

title: HIGHLIGHT WITH COLOR
description: Colors are great for drawing the eye to a certain location on the page. Try using color to highlight specific design elements.

title: MIX UP COLORS
description: While you want the colors on your web page to be consistent, that doesn’t mean leaving them the same for all eternity. Try using new colors, then test customer engagement.

title: RESIZE IMAGES
description: Wanna know the impact larger images will have on sales? Try using larger images for just 1 category of products and see what happens to your conversions.

title: SWITCH YOUR IMAGES
description: Which are more effective on the home page--product images or category images? Swap them and find out.

title: GO “TECH”
description: An interesting-looking graph or flow diagram is a great way to draw attention.

title: GET SMART
description: A clever or a humorous headline can compel customers to keep reading.

title: USE PRE-HEADER TEXT
description: Rather than putting your headline at the very top of the page, test the impact of pre-header text.

title: GO HIGHER
description: Change the height of your headline and see what customers prefer.

title: PUT OTHERS FIRST
description: Instead of bragging about your awesomeness in the headline (“We’re so great”), emphasize the benefit to consumers (“You’re so great, you deserve...”)

title: GO SHORTER (OR LONGER)
description: What sells best--a short or long headline? Try them both and see which has a greater impact.

title: GET BIZARRELY SPECIFIC
description: People find unusual numbers more believable. If it makes sense to do so, incorporate an odd number into your headline.

title: GET PERSONAL
description: If you aren’t already doing so, try using a personal pronoun in your headline (you, he, she, they).

title: MERGE FUNCTIONALITY
description: Rather than using multiple similar links on a page (Contact Us, Customer Service, etc.), combine them into just 1 link.

title: CURIOSITY WORKS
description: Asking a question in your headline is a great way to engage readers.

title: OFFER OPTIONS
description: Is your website stingy with its toolbar options? Try adding more options to see how users respond.

title: CHANGE IT UP
description: Try using a different design or navigational structure to test conversions and engagement.

title: BE UPFRONT
description: Research shows that a whopping 47% of consumers will abandon a shopping cart if they’re charged for shipping during checkout. Rather than leaving shipping charges a mystery until purchase, state the cost upfront on product pages. You might even want to consider adding a shipping calculator.

title: AVOID PREDICTABILITY
description: Predictable awards can get dull. Try variable rewards so consumers are compelled to return again and again.

title: TRY SHORTCUTS
description: Buttons aren’t bad, but heavy users may prefer using keyboard shortcuts instead.

title: DRAW ATTENTION TO RATINGS
description: By placing hover states over ratings, you can allow users to create their own rating or let them see a breakdown of the ratings (76 users rated this item 5 stars, 34 users rates this item 3 stars, etc.)

title: COLLAPSE SELECTIVELY
description: Rather than collapsing ALL search filters, try displaying just some of them, then test the impact.

title: REORDER FILTERS
description: Instead of organizing search filters haphazardly, why not try putting your most popular filters at the top of the page?

title: COLLAPSE FILTERS
description: Experiment with search filters by showing all of your main filter options (category, price, brand, etc.) while collapsing your subcategories (for instance, keeping the category closed, rather than displaying the items beneath it like Home, Clothing, Entertainment, etc.)

title: FOCUS ON BENEFIT
description: Create a site-wide tagline that emphasizes your value proposition.

title: HAIKUS: CREATIVITY AT ITS FINEST
description: Product descriptions/written in haiku format/may sell more products. That’s lines of 5-7-5 syllables if you want to give it a try.

title: ALTER YOUR “ABOUT US”
description: An “About Us” page is the perfect place to educate visitors on your mission and history. However, don’t just leave it at that. Add humor and personality to the page--consumers prefer that to dry corporate jargon.

title: ALTER YOUR CTA’S SHAPE
description: Some shapes might be more eye-catching than others. See if a new shape improves sales.

title: TEST YOUR TAGLINE
description: How’s your tagline working for you? Find out by changing it, then testing.

title: PLAY WITH HOVER STATES
description: Test different CTA hover states against each other to see how the states affect your conversion rates.

title: CHANGE COMPARE TEXT
description: Is there a way to compare multiple products on your site? If so, change the link text from “Compare” to “Compare Products” or vice versa.

title: CHANGE YOUR SOCIAL BUTTONS
description: What happens when you change the design of your social media buttons? Do you get less followers? More? Try it and find out.

title: INCREASE READABILITY
description: San-serif fonts are easier to read. If you’re still using Times Roman, mix it up by trying a font like Arial.

title: GO GRID
description: What impact does a grid image layout on your home page have?

title: TRY CONTINUITY
description: If your footer appears even when a user’s scrolling, test it against a footer that’s firmly affixed to the bottom of the page.

title: DISABLE CAROUSEL AUTO-SCROLL
description: Although a rotating carousel of images is not without its charms, it’s definitely less endearing when auto-scroll prevents consumers from spending time viewing an image that interests them. Disable auto-scroll and see what happens.

title: INCREASE FONT SIZE
description: If you offer consumers the option to compare products on your website, try increasing the size of your Compare link.

title: SIMPLIFY SEARCH
description: Don’t make visitors hunt products down. Increase the prominence of your search field so your site is easy to navigate.

title: TOUT YOUR TAGLINE
description: Does a user have to search to find your tagline? Make it larger and place it right next to your logo.

title: ENCOURAGE COMPARISONS
description: Make it easy for site visitors to perform comparisons by moving your Compare link closer to your product images.

title: MAKE SHARES A NO-BRAINER
description: By moving social share buttons above the fold, your site visitors will be much more likely to share your content with others.

title: DON’T OVERWHELM
description: It can be very helpful when a website recommends items customers might like. However, it can be overwhelming when all of those recommendations are for items very similar to something a consumer is already considering purchasing. Instead of doing that, why not recommend items that belong to a different product category?

title: SKIP THE FAST FOOD
description: Replacing the hamburger icon on your mobile site with the word, “MENU,” may lead to a significant increase in unique visitors to other areas of your website. At least, that’s what some companies have discovered--will it work for you?

title: TRY A DROP CAP
description: Bridge the gap between your headline and body copy by using a drop cap to begin your first paragraph.

title: CHANGE CONTENT CATEGORIES
description: Switch the order of your content categories to test whether you should be displaying different content at the top of your page.

title: GO MINIMAL
description: Rather than using images splashed with text, try copy-free images.

title: DEMAND ATTENTION
description: Body copy is typically skimmed. Make sure site visitors read the important stuff by selectively using bold text, highlighting, and italics.

title: SHOW YOUR STUFF
description: Don’t let your ratings and review stars get ignored! Increase their size so site visitors can’t help but notice.

title: SWITCH UP SOCIAL
description: Try moving your social media buttons around, then test the impact of their new location.

title: DITCH THE FAKEOUTS
description: If you have elements on your page that function like videos--but aren’t actually videos--try removing them.

title: GO 360
description: It’s frustrating when you want to see the tread on the bottom of a pair of sneakers but can’t. Rather than just using head-on shots of your products, offer a 360-degree view.

title: GET THE LOOK AND FEEL
description: Try moving your social media buttons around, then test the impact of their new location.

title: MESS WITH MOBILE
description: Which works better for your sales page--a dedicated mobile site or a mobile-responsive site? Try both and see.

title: PROVE IT
description: Show social proof on your sales page. For instance, you might include text like, “Over 15,000 happy customers.”

title: BE RESPONSIVE
description: If you’re not using a mobile-responsive sales page, create one and test it against your current sales page.

title: SWITCH IT UP
description: Your copy probably centers heavily around a main value proposition (MVP). Try changing your MVP to find out how prospects respond.

title: PUT PROSPECTS’ MINDS TO REST
description: Prospects like reassurances--add language like “no risk,” “cancel any time,” and “100% guaranteed.”

title: SOS, EMERGENCY, DIAL 911
description: Is there a reason prospects need to act on your offer TODAY? If so, let them know what it is. If not, find one. Adding an (honest) sense of urgency to your sales page is sure to improve your conversion rate.

title: VARY HEAD / HEART APPEALS
description: Which works best--an intellectual appeal or an emotional one?

title: CHOOSE BENEFITS
description: Lists of features don’t sell. Try replacing feature language (“100GB of storage”) with benefit language (“You’ll never EVER run out of space.”)

title: ADD A REVIEW
description: A personal story or review makes for a highly effective persuasion tactic. Try one in your sales page copy.

title: BONUSES ARE BENEFICIAL
description: Beneficial to conversions, that is. Think of a bonus you can offer prospects to sweeten your deal.

title: SELL WITH SCARCITY
description: Scarcity compels prospects to make purchases. If you only have “2 items left in stock,” then say so.

title: BE BULLISH (MAYBE)
description: In some markets, a hard sell might work better than a soft sell. Try both to discover which is most effective for your market.

title: ONCE UPON A TIME...
description: Instead of merely listing facts, try weaving a story around your product or service.

title: ADD TESTIMONIALS
description: Is your sales page devoid of testimonials? Try adding some to amp up sales.

title: GET CREDIBLE
description: Have you been relying on hype to sell? Add facts and figures to give your hype credibility.

title: KEEP ‘EM FROM FORGETTING
description: Make your CTA super-easy to find by having it scroll along with your user.

title: TEST(IMONIALS)
description: Yes, by all means, test using different testimonials!

title: GAIN TRUST
description: Trust seals are highly effective. Try adding different ones to your sales page to determine which combination of seals is most impactful.

title: SET LIMITS
description: When confronted with a difficult decision, many prospects will choose to walk away from a sale. Rather than offering tons of choice, keep product options limited.

title: RETHINK BENEFITS
description: Instead of using the same benefit in your headline that you use every time, why not try testing a different benefit?

title: VARY IT UP WITH VIDEO
description: Try replacing images with videos--videos are more engaging and have been shown to increase conversions.

title: TEASING IS TANTALIZING
description: Putting a teaser in the headline is a great way to capture your prospects’ attention.

title: ADD A VIDEO
description: If you don’t have a video on your sales page, try adding one to increase conversions.

title: FREE IS A BEAUTIFUL WORD
description: People love the word “free.” Try adding it to your headline to increase conversions.

title: HAVE SHIPPING GO HEAD-TO-HEAD
description: Which leads to higher sales--free shipping or a percent-off discount? Try both and see.

title: TRY TRIAL TESTING
description: Which works better--a free trial or a money-back guarantee? Try both and see.

title: DELIVER DISCOUNTS
description: Discounts have a huge impact on conversions--try testing various ones to see what percentage-off deal is most profitable.

title: GIVE A GIFT
description: A free gift is great. You know what makes it even better? When you’re allowed to keep it, even if you decide to return your purchase.

title: SAMPLE IT
description: People enjoy receiving free samples. If you have any samples to give, try including them as part of your offer.

title: TRY TRIALS
description: Does offering a trial membership increase conversions? Add one and see.

title: HAVE A SHIPPING SHOWDOWN
description: Try testing free shipping vs. a shipping fee to determine which is most profitable.

title: SEGMENT BASED ON RELATIONSHIP
description: Why not test two sales pages--one created for current customers and one specifically designed for non-customers?

title: APPEAL TO COMMITMENT-PHOBES
description: A smaller upfront commitment--like a monthly or quarterly fee--can be an easier ask than a larger commitment i.e. an annual fee.

title: VARY VOICE OVERS
description: If you’re using a video on your sales page, try switching the voice of your voice over. For instance, you could try a female voice, rather than a male one.

title: A BONUS BONANZA!
description: Try testing Bonus A against Bonus B to see which brings in the big bucks.

title: SPEED UP SLOW SALES PAGES
description: Can you optimize code to decrease the length of time it takes for your page to load?

title: USE POP-UPS
description: Do triggered pop-ups help or hinder your sales message? Add one and see.

title: REARRANGE CONTENT
description: The order of the content on your sales page matters. Try rearranging it to see what positioning is most effective.

title: ASK OFTEN (OR NOT)
description: What happens if you ask for the sale once? How about twice? Try both and see.

title: BE BOLD WITH BRIBES
description: Bribes can be a great way to get customers to read your sales copy. Try adding one toward the beginning of your page, “I urge you to read this letter all the way to the end if you want to have a happy and prosperous life.”

title: DITCH YOUR DESCRIPTION
description: Could a different product description sell much more? Try a new description and find out.

title: CUT YOUR INTRO
description: Is your intro too long? Alternatively, is it too short? Try varying the length of your intro to see what’s best.

title: ISOLATE IT
description: Rather than focusing on all the benefits of your product, try isolating one and really emphasizing it.

title: FIND THE RIGHT FIT
description: What works best--a long sales letter or a shorter one? Try both and see.

title: CHAT WITH A FRIEND
description: The best sales copy reads like one friend talking to another. If your copy doesn’t sound like that, rewrite it using this suggestion as a guideline.

title: VARY URGENCY
description: Urgent appeals work great, but are there some urgent appeals that work better than others? Try a variety of appeals to find out.

title: REGARDING THE WHY...
description: Your sales page probably emphasizes one main reason prospects need your solution. Try rewriting the copy using a different reason why they need it.

title: REPLACE PARAGRAPHS
description: Paragraphs tend to be skimmed. Try replacing the text in them with bullet points.

title: PERSONALITY IS APPRECIATED
description: Generic copy isn’t very inspiring. Try adding personality to your copy instead. For instance, you could liven it up by providing background information about yourself, the idea behind your product, etc.

title: REPOSITION YOUR CTA
description: Is your CTA in the perfect position? Try moving it around to find its ideal location.

title: BE ORIGINAL
description: “Click Here” and “Order Now” are commonplace. Can you think of original or offbeat text to use for your CTA?

title: CHANGE LINK ORDER
description: What would happen if you changed the order of your links and CTA? Test and find out.

title: REMOVE TASK-BASED BUTTONS
description: Rather than creating standard CTA copy (“Click Here Now”), try using benefit-based copy for your CTA (“Save Money Now!”).

title: SAY IT AGAIN
description: If you only have your CTA in one location on the page, try repeating it throughout your sales letter it to see if conversions increase.

title: DON’T BEAT AROUND THE BUSH
description: Rather than using indirect language in your CTA (“If You’re Interested, Click Here”), try being very direct (“Click Here Now”).

title: REMOVE YOUR GUARANTEE
description: In one conversion test, the removal of a guarantee--which was replaced by a trust seal--raised conversions by a whopping 107%!

title: REDO YOUR BACKGROUND
description: Some background images help conversion rates, some hurt them. Try switching up your background to see which category your current image falls into.

title: TRY A GRAPH
description: A graph is a great way to create visual interest on your sales page.

title: NO SURPRISES...
description: When prospects click an ad to reach your sales page, are they met with consistent elements or a jarring contrast? If your answer is the latter, aim to develop consistency between your ads and your sales page.

title: USE ILLUSTRATIONS & MIND MAPS
description: Mind maps are diagrams representing tasks or concepts related to a specific subject. Consider using them--or hand-drawn illustrations--on your landing page.

title: BE BRIEF (OR NOT)
description: Could your headline be shorter? Even longer? Try changing your headline to find out which length works best for your page.

title: ANCHOR YOUR PRICE
description: Try crossing out your suggested retail price and replacing it with your actual (cheaper) price.

title: BE SELECTIVE
description: Create a headline that says who your solution is for, rather than broadly targeting anyone who happens upon your sales page.

title: PULL A HOUDINI
description: Price illusions are super-effective at showing consumers an item’s true value. For instance, if you’re selling software, you might say something like, “You pay just .15 per template!”

title: PUMP IRON
description: Just as iron makes people stronger, adjectives and adverbs can strengthen a headline.

title: TRIAL LENGTH SHOWDOWN
description: Which works best--a 14-day trial or a 30-day trial? Surprisingly, one company found that shorter trials were more effective. Test to see if that holds true for your company.

title: TRY TIERS
description: If you’re not offering membership tiers, should you be? Try adding them to see how prospects respond.

title: SWITCH YOUR TARGET AUDIENCE
description: Does your product appeal to multiple audiences--for example, doctors, nurses, and medical students? If so, try creating a new sales page that’s been designed for a completely different audience than your current page.

title: SEGMENT THIS
description: Are you using a broad offer designed to appeal to the masses? If so, try creating an offer for a specific segment of the population.

title: PUT PROSPECTS AT THE CROSSROADS
description: A crossroads section can be highly effective in a sales letter. Put your prospects at the crossroads by including text like, “You can buy XYZ and have a wonderful life or you can ignore this offer and carry on in misery.” Perhaps use more subtlety than what’s shown in the example...

title: TOUT WHAT A BIG SPENDER YOU ARE
description: Are you offering a free gift that has a substantial value? Say exactly how much it costs.

title: FOCUS ON THE FUTURE
description: Try showing prospects a snapshot of the happy future they’ll experience if they buy your product (“Buy XYZ and you’ll wow people at your high school reunion, earn a million dollars overnight, etc.”)

title: RECOMMEND, RECOMMEND, RECOMMEND
description: Overwhelmed prospects will skip making purchases altogether. If you’re offering multiple items, try making a recommendation.

title: DEVELOP PERSPECTIVE
description: Does your sales page use he/she/we/me copy? Rewrite it from a different perspective by changing the personal pronouns you’re using.

title: ALLOW PEOPLE TO BE FREE
description: Nobody likes being told what to do. Reaffirm choice by reminding readers that they’re free to refuse your offer.

title: FOLLOW THE TRENDS
description: Is there a popular trending topic you can hook on to? Mention it in your sales copy.

title: BE CONCISE
description: Can you simplify your copy? Reread it and look for opportunities to use smaller words, shorter sentences, etc.

title: CONSIDER YOUR ASSUMPTIONS
description: Create a list of all the assumptions you have about your product and prospects. Now rewrite your copy assuming nobody knows what you do.

title: BE AUTHENTIC
description: Rather than using stock photos and fake reviews, use real reviews and photos of actual people.

title: USE CUES
description: Call attention to your CTA by using visual cues like directional arrows or irregular shapes.

title: YOU’VE GOT THE LOOK
description: Determine which is more effective for your sales page --a campaign-specific look or a brand-specific look.

title: LIVEN IT UP
description: Could your sales page benefit from animated gifs? Add one or two and find out.

title: ALTER ALIGNMENT
description: Would your copy perform better if it was centered, rather than left-justified? Test and find out.

title: REDESIGN YOUR PROOF
description: There are plenty of different ways you can display social proof--with large quotes around it, in a bordered box, italicized, etc. Experiment with the way you display social proof on your sales page to see which design works best.

title: MAKE IT SIMPLE
description: If you’re comparing multiple products on your sales page, don’t create confusion for prospects by designing difficult-to-read tables.

title: RELOCATE YOUR TESTIMONIALS
description: Would your testimonials be more impactful if they were higher on the page? Move them and find out.

title: USE YOUR REPRESENTATIVES
description: Do you have spokespeople or brand ambassadors? If so, why not try adding photos of them to your sales page?

title: SHOW YOUR STUFF
description: Including a professional photo of deliverables on your sales page is a great idea, if you’re not doing it already.

title: SHOW THE DESIRED OUTCOME
description: Is there an image that perfectly represents the happy outcome the prospect will experience if they buy your product? If so, add it to your page.

title: GET CLEVER
description: A clever or humorous headline may work wonders on your conversion rate. Try one for yourself and see.

title: SHOW YOU CARE
description: Rather than putting your business first (“Buy from us because we’re the best,”) create a headline that puts others first i.e. “Buy from us because you deserve the best.”

title: AVERT LOSS
description: Rather than emphasizing gains (“Do this to earn money”), create a headline around loss aversion (“Do this to avoid losing money.”).

title: SUBHEADERS HELP
description: Can’t get all the important stuff into your headline? Try adding a subheader.

title: CONSIDER PRE-HEADER TEXT
description: Pre-header text can improve the messaging of your headline. Add it and then do some testing.

title: BE ODDLY SPECIFIC
description: Somewhat oddly, oddly specific numbers in headlines are compelling to prospects. If you’re not using one already, give this tactic a try.

title: PERCENTAGES HAVE POWER
description: Percentages are also attention-grabbers. Try putting one into your headline to get prospects’ notice.

title: THINK OUTSIDE THE BOX
description: Have a brainstorming session with employees to come up with an unexpected offer--then, use it on your sales page.

title: USE “YOU”
description: The word “you” in a headline can be very effective--add it to your headline and see for yourself.

title: CREATE COMBOS
description: Combine complementary products together and then sell them as a complete, everything-you-need package.

title: COPYWRITING LISTS ARE YOUR FRIENDS
description: Look online to find lists of the most powerful words in copywriting, then incorporate some of them into your headline.

title: CHAT WITH PROSPECTS
description: Including chat capability on your sales page may be an effective way to overcome buyer objections.

title: POSTSCRIPTS ARE POWERFUL
description: Copywriters know that while people tend to skim body copy, they’ll typically read a PS. Take advantage of this by creating a powerful postscript.

title: PLEASED TO MEET YOU
description: If you’re not doing so already, try introducing yourself or your team to prospects.

title: AIM FOR JUST ONE BULLET
description: What would happen if you changed just ONE bullet point? Discover the answer by testing.

title: NAMES MATTER
description: Could the name of your product be hindering sales? Try renaming it--if only on your sales page--to find out.

title: DETAIL, DETAIL, DETAIL!
description: Don’t leave orders to chance. Instead of skimming over ordering details, be very clear about what customers can expect if they make a purchase.

title: HUMOR HELPS
description: Humorous copy is virtually always more enjoyable to read than serious copy. Try adding humor to your copy to see how prospects respond.

title: USE YOUR PS
description: Add a CTA to your PS for maximum effectiveness.

title: ALTER PRODUCT IMAGES
description: Take multiple pictures of your product, then test picture A against picture B, for example.

title: OPT FOR COLOR
description: What happens when you increase the color contrast of your CTA?

title: JUST ADD PEOPLE?
description: Some sales pages use images of products by themselves, while others display images of people using those products--try both to see what works best for your sales page.

title: AVOID SCATTERING ATTENTION
description: Too many boxes and borders make a sales page look cluttered. Try removing some to give your page a cleaner appearance.

title: PLAY WITH COLOR
description: Colors impact the entire look and feel of a landing page. See how effective your current colors are by testing them against new ones.

title: USE HIGHLIGHTS
description: Try using color to highlight a specific design element--then test its success.

title: SEPARATE ITEMS
description: Visual hierarchy helps you clearly establish which elements on the sales page are important and which are less so.

title: ACHIEVE MORE WITH LESS
description: Rather than using images with lots of copy on them, see how well images with minimal copy work on your sales page.

title: CHANGE DIMENSIONS
description: Is your headline too big or too small? Play around with size to perfect your headline’s dimensions.

title: CLARITY CONVERTS
description: Rather than using an ambiguous design, make things as clear as possible.

title: JUST ASK
description: Questions work well in headlines. Rather than merely stating facts in your headline, try asking a question instead.

title: JUST ONE MORE THING...
description: Add a 2nd PS to your sales letter and see how prospects respond.

title: THE EYES HAVE IT
description: Do more people click on your CTA when you use an image of someone looking directly at it?

title: BE CHARMING
description: Instead of using a standard PS, why not create a PS that uses an image of handwritten script?

title: SAN SERIF SELLS
description: San serif fonts increase readability and have even been shown to improve conversions by as much as 30%. If you’re not using a san serif typeface on your sales page, give it a try.

title: SIMPLIFY SHARES
description: Consider allowing social commitments i.e. letting customers share on Facebook or Twitter that they just purchased your item.

title: USE DIFFERENT DEMOGRAPHICS
description: Vary your images by testing photos that include people of different ages, races, genders, etc.

title: CHOOSE A RESPONSIVE LAYOUT
description: Try designing your website to respond accordingly, based on the device the user is accessing it from.

title: VARY URGENT APPEALS
description: Urgent appeals are a great way to get customers to act on your CTA. Try testing various appeals (i.e. a countdown timer vs. “Sale ends Sunday at midnight” text) against each other to see what works best.

title: INCLUDE SOCIAL PROOF
description: Testimonials and other forms of social proof on the order form can help overcome buyer reluctance.

title: ADD TRUST SEALS
description: Trust seals are a great way to quickly reassure customers that their purchase is secure.

title: TRY SCARCITY
description: Only have 3 medium-sized pink sweaters in stock? Let customers know so they’re more inclined to complete the purchase.

title: ADD AN ORDER BUMP
description: An order bump lets you display complementary products on your order page. Once customers make their product selection, give them the option to add “bump products” to their order.

title: REMOVE NAVIGATION
description: Distracted users are less likely to make purchases. Try removing navigation on checkout pages so customers are more likely to complete the sale.

title: EXPERIMENT WITH PERCENTAGES
description: How successful are 20% discounts? What about 33%? Test them against each other to see how they measure up.

title: ADD A BONUS
description: Bonuses add to the value of a purchase. Consider adding a bonus so customers are more likely to make a purchase.

title: OFFER A TRIAL
description: Because trial memberships are less of a commitment, they can be used to overcome buyer objections.

title: ADD AN ORDER BUMP
description: An order bump lets you display complementary products on your order page. Once customers make their product selection, give them the option to add “bump products” to their order.

title: FORGIVING INPUTS
description: Be forgiving--rather than strict--by allowing customers to input data like phone numbers in multiple ways.

title: REMOVE LINKS
description: By removing links from checkout pages, you can keep customers hyper-focused on completing your CTA.

title: SIMPLIFY THE CHECKOUT PROCESS
description: Consider testing a 1-page checkout process against a multi-page checkout process.

title: ADD REASSURANCES
description: Reassurances can overcome buyer objections. Consider adding one of the following phrases to your checkout pages: 100% risk-free, cancel any time, secure checkout.

title: ADD VIDEO
description: Worried your customer may not understand what to do? Try adding a video explaining the ordering process.

title: CREATE URGENCY
description: While you don’t want to lie to your customers, creating an honest sense of urgency (i.e. a simple countdown timer) can prompt them to act.

title: ALTER FONT SIZE
description: See if making the font smaller or larger improves sales.

title: USE CONSISTENCY
description: Keep checkout pages unified by using consistent colors, shapes, labels, and language throughout.

title: ADD SHIPPING OPTIONS
description: Customers appreciate flexibility. More Shipping Options = More Choice.

title: USE PRODUCT IMAGE PHOTO
description: Does adding a product image on your checkout pages increase sales? Test and see.

title: ADD PAYMENT OPTIONS
description: The more ways you offer to pay, the less likely you are to lose customers along the way. Consider adding PayPal if haven’t already done so.

title: USE MORE OR LESS FORM FIELDS
description: Some customers won’t complete a purchase if there’s too much they have to fill out. Try adding or removing form fields to see which layout fares better.

title: DISPLAY COUPON CODES
description: Customers who leave your site to look for a coupon code may never return. Try putting them right on your site to maintain customers’ focus.

title: TRY AN EXIT POP-UP BOX
description: If customers attempt to navigate away from your page without completing an order, a pop-up box offering a discount can compel them to purchase.

title: MAKE EMAIL OPTIONAL
description: Not everyone is comfortable providing an email address and plenty of people don’t even HAVE email. Consider making this field optional.

title: APPEAL TO RISK-ADVERSE USERS
description: There are still plenty of people who aren’t comfortable with the idea of submitting an order online. If someone starts to leave your checkout page, consider a pop-up box suggesting they call to place their order instead.

title: MAKE PHONE NUMBER OPTIONAL
description: Many people are reluctant to share their phone number. Try making this field optional, rather than required.

title: EXPERIMENT WITH DISCOUNT TYPES
description: What’s more impactful--free shipping or % off discounts? Test and find out.

title: GIVE SECOND CHANCES
description: If a user submits an order that doesn’t go through correctly, allow him to easily resubmit it a 2nd time.

title: SHOW PROGRESS
description: Don’t lose customers along the way. Keep them interested by showing their progress (“You’re halfway through the signup process.”)

title: CREATE COMBINATIONS
description: Repackaging products into combinations may increase overall sales.

title: EXPLAIN, DON’T ASSUME
description: Instead of just asking customers to enter a CVC code, explain that it’s the 3-digit code on the back of their credit card.

title: SWITCH UP TEXT
description: See what impact changing the text on your order button has on sales.

title: MAKE RECOMMENDATIONS
description: When customers are checking out, let them know about other items that are frequently purchased with the items they have in their cart.

title: USE CREDIT CARD IMAGES
description: Credit card images present on the page will quickly communicate to your customers which payment methods you accept.

title: FOLLOW CONVENTION
description: Customers have certain expectations when they’re purchasing online. Rather than being unconventional, follow standard web development guidelines--ordinary fonts, back button on the left, etc. Your checkout pages aren’t the place to try bucking the norm.

title: TRY FAMILIARITY
description: By using familiar images, you can improve the overall look of the page. Experiment by adding a UPS or FedEx symbol next to your shipping options.

title: GO BIG(GER)
description: Increasing the size of your form fields may make checkout pages look more appealing.

title: MERGE FUNCTIONALITY
description: Rather than having multiple links that are similar (Contact Us, Customer Service, etc.), try combining them into just 1 link.

title: CHANGE SUMMARY PLACEMENT
description: Find out what happens when you change the placement of the order summary area.

title: USE AMAZON
description: Amazon has tons of brand-loyal customers. If someone tries to leave your checkout pages, try a pop-up box giving them the opportunity to purchase your product on Amazon.

title: GIVE SAMPLES
description: Free samples sweeten the deal for customers. They can also introduce customers to new items they might wish to purchase in the future.

title: USE SMALLER COMMITMENTS
description: Rather than charging an annual fee, experiment by offering a smaller monthly fee.

title: VARY SHIPPING OFFERS
description: How many sales do you get with free shipping? $3 shipping? $6 flat rate? Test and see.

title: TRY DIFFERENT BONUSES
description: Some bonuses may be more successful than others. Try testing Bonus A against Bonus B to see which one is more successful.

title: USE PRICE ILLUSIONS
description: Price illusions increase the perception of value. For instance, if you’re selling a case of something, you may want to remind your customer that each item in the case costs just X dollars.

title: USE LOCATION
description: Rather than forcing users to enter city, state, and ZIP code, why not try auto-filling your form based on the user’s location?

title: USE GENTLE PROMPTS
description: A lot of people find pop-up windows annoying. Instead of using them, consider a subtler prompt like an inline or slide-out one.

title: SIMPLIFY DATA ENTRY
description: To make numeric entries easy, try defaulting the mobile keyboard to numbers instead of letters.

title: CONSIDER INLINE VALIDATION
description: Try letting customers know immediately that the data they’ve entered needs to be corrected, rather than only showing errors after they’ve hit the submit button.

title: DECREASE PAGE LOAD TIMES
description: Nobody likes to wait a long time for a page to load. By optimizing code, customers are more likely to stick around.

title: ADD THE MONTH NUMBER
description: Adding the month number to the date field makes it easier for users to enter dates quickly.

title: DON’T OVERWHELM
description: Avoid showing customers more information than they need. Progressive disclosures allow them to only view relevant information. For instance, if shipping is delayed in certain parts of the country due to bad weather, you only need to display that information to people living in certain zip codes.

title: USE SMART DEFAULTS
description: Reduce the data customers need to enter by using defaults when possible. For instance, you could populate city and state based on the user’s zip code.

title: OFFER SOCIAL COMMITMENTS
description: Once the sale’s complete, allow customers to post on Facebook that they just bought XYZ item from your company.

title: OFFER EASY UNDOS
description: Instead of asking customers, “Are you sure you want to make this change?” try “Your change has been saved. Click here if you want to undo it.”

title: DON’T CROWD
description: You don’t want elements to look too squished together. Instead, opt for extra padding to increase readability.

title: SET EXPECTATIONS
description: Rather than just listing shipping methods, tell customers when they can expect their order if they choose air, ground, etc.

title: PROVIDE PROMPTS
description: Once a customer has made a purchase, thank them and prompt them to another action. For instance, you might suggest they post about their purchase on Facebook or encourage them to check out another item.

title: MOVE INPUT BOXES
description: Swapping the location of credit card number and billing address (or vice versa) may result in more sales.

title: CHANGE COLORS
description: Do some colors work better than others? Find out by trying different colors on your checkout pages.

title: POP-UP SHIPPING OPTIONS
description: By using a pop-up box for users to enter shipping options, you can make your checkout process seem shorter.

title: RETURNS MATTER
description: Having to return something you bought online can be a real pain. Instead of forcing your customers to jump through hoops to return something, why not promote your free & easy return policy?

title: VARY THE LAYOUT
description: Using multiple columns? Try testing it against a single column layout to see which is more effective.

title: CHANGE ORDER BUTTON COLOR
description: Green means go. Red means stop. Orange means caution. Try different colors to see which encourages more people to click the order button.

title: TRY ICON LABELS
description: Rather than assuming your customers know what a trash can means, add a label that says, “Delete.”

title: ADD REASSURANCES
description: Your spouse isn’t the only one who needs reassurance--your customers do too! Add reassurances (no risk, cancel any time, 100% guarantee) to your emails to increase conversions.

title: GO PINK OR BLUE
description: Gender-specific content can increase reader engagement.

title: PROVE IT
description: Social proof can be very persuasive. Remind users just how popular you are by including text like, “Over 1,000 users,” etc.

title: CONSIDER INTERESTS
description: If you have information about your recipients’ interests, try creating copy designed to specifically appeal to those interests.

title: DO SOME REPOSITIONING
description: Have you been extolling the virtues of your free 2-day shipping? Try mixing things up by changing your main value proposition and then testing.

title: USE PREFERENCES
description: During the email signup process, did you ask consumers what type of content they wanted to receive? If the answer is yes, create content around those preferences.

title: LIGHT A FIRE
description: The most successful appeals create a sense of urgency. While you don’t want to lie to your recipients, you should give them a compelling reason to act now (limited supply available, sale ends in 3 hours, etc.)

title: STORIES SELL
description: A personal story or review is a highly effective persuasive tactic.

title: TALK TRENDS
description: Emails about popular trending topics do an excellent job of capturing your recipients’ interest.

title: DON’T MESS WITH SUCCESS
description: Did you have an email campaign that hit it out of the park last year? Use it again!

title: SWAP HEAD AND HEART
description: Are your appeals more intellectual or emotional? Whatever your answer is, change your appeal type and test the results.

title: USE SCARCITY
description: Are your widgets flying off the shelves? Let your subscriber list know. Scarcity is a great conversion tactic.

title: TRY BOLD BENEFITS
description: Many businesses promote features to their own detriment. Rather than focusing on your product’s specifications, consider how those features make users’ lives easier--then, write copy around those benefits.

title: DON’T FORGET TO UPSELL
description: Use what you know about customers’ previous purchases to upsell items you think they’ll like.

title: TELL A STORY
description: Instead of simply listing facts, create a story around your product that weaves relevant information in.

title: TESTIFY
description: Include testimonials from happy customers in your emails. Your sales message is much more persuasive if it comes from other users, rather than your marketing department.

title: PROMOTE CREDIBILITY
description: Are your emails all hype? i.e. We’re the best, our product is the greatest... While hype isn’t a bad thing per se, adding some specific facts and figures may improve your appeal’s success.

title: PLAY WITH PRODUCT MIX
description: Try sending emails featuring just one product vs. emails featuring multiple products to find the right balance.

title: USE CAMOUFLAGE
description: People are inclined to tune ads out. Rather than using your typical ad-like design, why not try sending an email that doesn’t resemble an ad?

title: USE DISCOUNT VARIATIONS
description: Test the impact of offering different discounts. For instance, you might try testing a 20% discount against a 25% one.

title: VARY THE LAYOUT
description: If you’re using multiple columns, try a single column layout--or vice versa--to see which works best.

title: GIVE IT AWAY
description: Free samples do 2 things: (1) they increase the likelihood of a purchase and (2) they introduce customers to new products they might then buy in the future. Try offering free samples in your next email.

title: FROM JIM...
description: Test email open rates by using your company name in the from field vs. your actual name.

title: CHANGE YOUR DEALS
description: Try testing free shipping vs. % off discounts to determine which deal offers maximum profitability.

title: TRI(AL) IT OUT
description: Overcome buyer reluctance by offering a trial or test membership.

title: GO BROAD (OR NOT)
description: Which works better--a broad offer or one segmented for a specific audience? Try both and see.

title: DON’T BE SHY ABOUT PRESALES
description: Have a big sale coming up? Don’t wait until the day of to let your customers know. Send an email in advance to get them excited about the big event.

title: SEGMENT BASED ON RELATIONSHIP
description: Are you sending the same email to customers and non-customers alike? Try sending different emails to each.

title: VARY YOUR WELCOME EMAIL
description: Most businesses offer a discount when people subscribe to their email list. Test this tactic against NOT mentioning a discount and then sending one unexpectedly in that oh-so-important first email.

title: SEGMENT BASED ON ENGAGEMENT
description: Some of your email recipients probably act on most of your CTAs, while some might open all of your emails but never make a purchase. Try split-testing emails based on customers’ levels of engagement.

title: USE RFM
description: Recency, Frequency, and Monetary value. Try segmenting your list based on how recent, how often, and how much they’ve bought from you.

title: OFFER A FREE REPORT
description: In some markets, a free report is highly desirable. Consider offering one and including the words “free report” in your subject line.

title: CHANGE SUBJECT LINES
description: Your subject line is one of the most important elements of your email. Not sure whether yours is compelling enough? Test 2 different versions of it.

title: SEND BY SEASON
description: If you’re not already sending emails triggered by season, start doing so and test the impact.

title: TRY TEASING
description: A subject line that teases or hints at something typically generates higher open rates than emails with straightforward subject lines.

title: RESEND TO NON-OPENERS
description: Did your email go unopened? Try resending it and measure the results.

title: WAIT A FEW MONTHS...
description: Find an email you sent more than 3 months ago and resend it. Are the results different from what you expected?

title: JUST BECAUSE
description: Consumers are bombarded with promotional emails. Rather than sending an email with a sales message, try sending a non-selling email for a change.

title: GET SPECIFIC
description: Play with the design of your emails, optimizing them for different desktop and mobile browsers.

title: TEASING WORKS
description: When you have something big coming up--for instance, a website redesign or new product launch--a teaser email is the perfect way to foster curiosity. Send an email hinting at what’s to come but shhhh...don’t reveal your secret right away.

title: PUT A PS ON IT
description: A PS is a great attention-grabber--because it stands out, it has a great chance of being read by your recipients.

title: SPLIT IT UP
description: Rather than saying it all in one email, split your content into multiple emails and test the impact on open rates and conversions.

title: ALTER YOUR UNSUBSCRIBE LINK
