description: Many companies bury their Unsubscribe links in footer navigation. Try moving yours to the top of the page to reduce spam complaints.

title: SWITCH UP INCENTIVES
description: If you offer ebooks, webinars, and white papers for free, try switching them up by offering something new.

title: SHOW THE RIGHT STUFF
description: Use customers’ profile information to show them personalized imagery.

title: 14-DAYS VS. 30-DAYS?
description: Rather than offering the typical 30-day trial, why not test a 14-day free trial instead?

title: ANCHOR IT
description: People love getting a deal. Try anchoring your price by showing 2 prices. For instance, you could show a suggested retail price of $199, cross it out, and next to it, display an actual price of $99.

title: ANALYZE COUPONING
description: What works best--sending users a coupon code or offering a direct link to discounted merchandise?

title: PROMOTE YOUR PRICE
description: Rather than burying your price in the body of the email, put it right at the top so customers can’t miss it.

title: CREATE EXCITEMENT WITH A CONTEST
description: A contest is a great way to engage your customers. Consider a naming contest or hold a prize drawing--either will generate brand enthusiasm.

title: DO SOMETHING UNEXPECTED
description: An unexpected offer can catch customers by surprise--in a good way. If you run the same deals all of the time, do some brainstorming to come up with an offer that’s outside the box.

title: SHOUT OUT TO YOUR FOLLOWERS
description: Try testing specific messages to your Facebook and/or Twitter followers.

title: TAKE A TACTIC FROM HOUDINI’S PLAYBOOK
description: Use price illusions by telling customers just how much of a value your product really is. For example, if you sell software that creates 500 different form letters, include text that says, “Pay just .10 per form letter!”

title: SAY WHO YOU ARE (OR NOT)
description: Try testing 2 versions of your subject line: one that includes your company name and one that doesn’t.

title: PUT YOUR CTA IN THE SUBJECT LINE
description: Be bold by adding your CTA to your subject line.

title: USE INDIVIDUALIZED SEND TIMES
description: Not sure of the best time to send your emails? Test individualized send times against universal send times to pinpoint the answer.

title: TIRED OF AN ACHING BACK?
description: Address a pain point in the subject line of an email to increase your open rates.

title: ADJUST SENDING FREQUENCY
description: How often should you send emails--once a week? Twice a week? Daily? Test sending frequency to discover what your customers prefer.

title: DELIVER BY TIME ZONE
description: Is it more effective to send your emails by time zone or all at once? Try both and see.

title: SEND A WELCOME EMAIL SERIES
description: A welcome email series may have more of an impact than a single email. Test both versions and find out.

title: ENGAGE USERS WITH WISHLISTS
description: If a customer’s birthday or a holiday is approaching, use it as an incentive for creating a wishlist on your website. Even better, allow them to share it.

title: GET CLEVER
description: A clever or humorous subject line will make your email stand out in a recipient’s inbox.

title: VARY YOUR INTRO
description: Is an intro written by the CEO really the most effective intro for your business? Test it against a different type of intro and see which is most successful.

title: COMBINE EMAILS
description: Try combining multiple emails into just one and testing the impact.

title: SO YOU’VE BEEN REJECTED...
description: Rather than focusing on what’s so great about your business, try changing your text to one that’s more customer-centric (the benefits the customer will experience if they come back).

title: ELICIT CURIOSITY
description: The most compelling copywriters know the value of teasers and hooks. Include them in your email to make your recipients want to keep reading.

title: CREATE BALANCE
description: What’s the ideal balance of content between your email and your landing page? Find out by testing.

title: BE STINGY WITH CHOICES
description: Research has found that customers with too many choices often struggle to reach a decision and end up not making a purchase at all. If you’re trying to be all things to all people, consider cutting back on your offerings to drive sales.

title: THINGS THAT MAKE YOU GO HMMM...
description: Rather than assuming that HTML is the way to go with your customers (because it’s prettier), try testing a plain-text email and see what happens. You may find deliverability increases significantly.

title: USE BENEFIT-RICH BULLETS
description: Benefits + Bullets = Marketing Success. If you’re not doing so already, create ultra-specific bullet points that really sell the benefits of your products.

title: VARY YOUR VISUALS
description: What works best with your clientele-- image-heavy emails or text-heavy ones? Try both and see.

title: SURPRISE YOUR READERS
description: A lot of people really appreciate being asked their opinion. Take advantage of that by surprising your readers with polls, quizzes, or surveys in your next email.

title: PUT YOUR PERSONALITY ON DISPLAY
description: Generic text isn’t very interesting. Show off bits and pieces of your personality (or your company culture) to keep readers’ attention.

title: HYPNOTIZE YOUR READERS
description: Well, don’t hypnotize them exactly but DO try repeating your CTA to see if repetition increases clicks.

title: MINIMIZE LINKS
description: Get your subscriber list hyper-focused on your CTA by minimizing the number of links in your email.

title: SPICE IT UP
description: Animated gifs work in most desktop/mobile clients and all web clients. Consider making your email more engaging by including an animated gif.

title: SWITCH IT UP
description: Try reversing the order of your links--and your CTA, too--then test the impact on conversions.

title: GET REAL
description: Rather than faking it, try using real reviews and photos of actual people.

title: APPEAL TO POPULARITY
description: What are your most popular items? Create an email focusing on the items your customers buy the most often.

title: CUT IT
description: People tend to scan long paragraphs. Try using shorter paragraphs to get your message across.

title: FOLLOW UP WITH ABANDON
description: Did someone visit your site and abandon a full shopping cart? Remind them to complete their order. If you want, you can even include an incentive to compel them to complete their purchase.

title: PROMOTE SPECIALNESS
description: Is there a big sale day or a special event coming up? Promote it in your email!

title: VARY YOUR SALES PITCH
description: While you don’t want to come off sounding like a used car salesman, you do want to experiment with the tone of your sales pitch. Swap a hard sales pitch for a softer one or vice versa.

title: LISTS ROCK
description: For whatever reason, people tend to enjoy reading lists (i.e. The Top 5 Ways to...10 Reasons You Should...). Experiment with lists and see how your subscribers respond.

title: DON’T BE SHY
description: If you’re selling multiple items, don’t be afraid to make a recommendation to your email recipients. Recommendations can be based on their interests, demographics, or previous purchase behavior.

title: WHY (OR WHY NOT)?
description: Why should someone purchase from you? Test out various whys to see which packs the greatest punch.

title: HOLD A CONVERSATION
description: Dry, textbook-like copy is boring. Try appealing to your customer in the same way you’d talk to a friend.

title: DITCH THE INTRO
description: Do you really need an intro in your emails? Remove it and find out.

title: COLLABORATE WITH THIRD PARTIES
description: Would you benefit from collaborating with a third party? Test and see. Try offering third party content or products and seeing how your email recipients react.

title: BE SELECTIVE
description: Rather than trying to appeal to everyone, say exactly who your solution’s for in your copy.

title: BE EXCLUSIVE
description: Exclusivity increases desirability. Use this to your advantage. For example, you could limit the availability of a product or service, then ask people to sign up and wait for their exclusive invite.

title: CHANGE YOUR CLOSE
description: Do you regularly close your emails in a casual way or are you more formal? Whatever your answer is, change your tactic and test.

title: GREED WORKS
description: Try appealing to your subscribers’ greedy nature and testing how they respond.

title: HOHOHO...THE HOLIDAYS ARE HERE
description: Rather than sending holiday promotions to everyone on your subscriber list, why not try using holiday-specific promotions based on location?

title: DON’T FORGET TO FOLLOW UP
description: Are people downloading your content? Take advantage of their interest by following up.

title: BE BRIEF...OR NOT
description: What’s the ideal email length? It depends on what you’re trying to accomplish. Try testing various copy lengths against each other by creating emails with long copy, short copy, and very short copy.

title: CHANGE THE DAY...
description: Do you always send emails on Wednesdays? Try sending an email on a Monday or Tuesday and see what happens to your open rates.

title: MENTION MONEY
description: Are you giving something free away? Don’t be shy--let your audience know the value of your free gift.

title: ALTER REDEMPTION TIME
description: Planning to offer a flash sale? Try testing various redemption times.

title: ADD PREHEADER TEXT
description: If you’re not doing so already, consider adding preheader text to your emails. Preheader text is the short summary text following the subject line when an email’s viewed in an inbox.

title: OPTIMIZE CODE
description: Emails that take too long to open get deleted. Try optimizing code to make emails open rapidly.

title: CHANGE YOUR PERSPECTIVE
description: In the text of your email, you probably use personal pronouns like you/he/she/we. Try writing from a different perspective, swapping out “we” for “you,” for example.

title: JUST SAY CHEESE
description: Are images of people using your products better than images of the product by itself? Find out!

title: CREATIVELY USE YOUR PS
description: Typically, a PS is done in plain text. However, if you want to really grab attention, try using an image of handwritten script instead.

title: HIGHLIGHT BRAND AMBASSADORS
description: Create an email highlighting a spokesperson or one of your brand ambassadors.

title: COMPLETELY REDO YOUR DESIGN
description: Is there another email design you could use that would be more appealing to your target audience? Swap designs and see.

title: SOMETIMES LESS IS MORE
description: Rather than using images that contain lots of text, try swapping them for images with minimal (or no) copy.

title: PEOPLE APPRECIATE PERSONALIZATION
description: A personal touch can be nice. Try adding your subscriber’s first name in the body copy of your email.

title: BONUSES DELIVER
description: Consider offering bonuses in your emails. Bonuses tend to go over big with consumers.

title: APPEAL TO VIDEO FANS
description: Have a video to share? Try putting [video] in the subject line.

title: ADD UNICODE
description: Try putting Unicode symbols in your subject line to grab recipients’ attention.

title: RE WORKS
description: When people see RE: in the subject line, there’s always a moment where they wonder, “What did I contact XYZ Company about?” Try using this tactic and measuring the response you get.

title: USE PERSONALIZATION
description: Mentioning recipients by name in the subject line is a good way to get their attention.

title: USE STRONG ADJECTIVES AND ADVERBS
description: Strong words in your subject line pack a punch. Try using words like remarkable, sensational, startling, quick, easy, etc.

title: AIM FOR BREVITY
description: Create a subject line that’s shorter than what you typically use and see how well it does, compared to your “normal” subject lines.

title: REACH OUT BY NAME
description: Rather than just using the standard subject line in your abandonment emails (“You forgot something.”) why not try adding someone’s first name (“You forgot something, Ashley.”)?

title: USE ODDLY SPECIFIC NUMBERS
description: The best copywriters know that oddly specific numbers are attention-grabbing. Try using one in the subject line of your emails.

title: ASK A QUESTION
description: Ask a question in your email subject line to capture readers’ interest.

title: USE PERSONAL PRONOUNS
description: Wanna get noticed? Try using the word, “you,” in the subject line i.e. You need to see this.

title: HELLO, BONJOUR, OR HOLA?
description: Try testing different variations of the subject line you’re using in your welcome email.

title: REWRITE PRODUCT DESCRIPTION COPY
description: Product description copy can make or break a sale. Try rewriting it to see whether version A, B, or C is most effective.

title: GET CREATIVE
description: Loyalty points and customer levels can compel customers to spend more.

title: INTRODUCE YOURSELF
description: Consumers enjoy companies that offer a personal touch. Take advantage of that by creating an email that introduces your team.

title: IN WITH THE NEW...
description: Did new products just come in? Create an email promoting the newest items in stock.

title: ISOLATE A BENEFIT
description: By focusing on just one benefit, you can test various benefits against each other to see which leads to higher conversions.

title: RESTRAIN YOUR EGO
description: Why should someone purchase from you? Test out various whys to see which packs the greatest punch.

title: MIX IT UP
description: If you’re using image-based CTAs, try replacing them with text-link CTAs or vice versa.

title: TEST YOUR LINKS
description: Discover what works best--just a few links or lots of them.

title: MULTIPLY YOUR CTAS
description: Try testing multiple CTAs on a page versus having just one.

title: SERVE UP SOME EGGS
description: Easter eggs are intentional inside jokes, hidden messages, or secret interactive features. Consider adding Easter eggs to your emails to spike engagement.

title: DRAW ATTENTION
description: Arrows and other visual cues can be very effective at drawing attention to your CTA.

title: GET NOTICED
description: Directional arrows and irregular shapes are a great way to direct readers’ attention.

title: DON’T HESITATE
description: While saying this might get you more friends in real life: “Would you be interested in doing XYZ?” To sell more, be direct by saying, “Click Here Now!”

title: DON’T BE A SLUG
description: It’s tempting to use the same old text every time you create a CTA--Learn More or Click Here. Try thinking outside the box and using a creative CTA for a change.

title: DON’T ASSUME
description: By writing down your assumptions--and then assuming nobody else shares them--you can improve your copy’s effectiveness.

title: USE BENEFIT BUTTONS
description: Benefit buttons (“Save Money Now!”) can be more compelling than task-oriented buttons (“Sign Up Now”).

title: USE CLICK INDICATORS
description: The more user-friendly your site is, the more time customers will spend on it. Click indicators can help with that objective. Try adding them to your CTAs so people can visually see their site interactions.

title: EXPERIMENT WITH CTA POSITION
description: Change your CTA’s location to see if customer response improves.

title: USE PSYCHOLOGY
description: Nobody likes being told what to do. Use reverse psychology by reaffirming freedom (“It’s your choice, you’re free to ignore this offer.”)

title: CREATE COMBOS
description: By repackaging products into combinations, you can sell complementary items together that might otherwise be overlooked.

title: DON’T FORGET UPDATES & REMINDERS
description: Try testing reminders and service updates to see how users react.

title: BE BIG ON BULLETS
description: Long blocks of copy tend to go ignored. Use bullet points so readers can easily scan the main points you want to make.

title: RENAME IT
description: Could your product or service name stand to be improved? Try changing it (even if only in your email) to see.

title: GET OUT YOUR CHOPPING BLOCK
description: Write shorter sentences and eliminate unnecessary text so your copy is clear and concise.

title: GET THE RIGHT LOOK
description: Which works better--emails using your brand’s look and feel or campaign-specific designs? Try both and see.

title: FIND THE PERFECT FONT SIZE
description: Does your email readership tend to skew older? Using a larger font may increase your conversion rate.

title: LAND CORRECTLY
description: Do your emails direct readers to category landing pages or product landing pages? Change what you’re doing currently and see which landing page links are most impactful.

title: REORGANIZE FROM THE TOP DOWN
description: Try this for a change: move your primary text, imagery, and CTA ABOVE your email header and navigation.

title: REDUCE BOXES & BORDERS
description: Too many boxes and borders can be distracting. Reduce the number of them so attention isn’t scattered.

title: USE THE POPULARITY OF PINTEREST
description: With 150 million users, Pinterest is a force to be reckoned with, particularly if your target demographic is women. If your customers are primarily female, consider creating a Pinterest-style email to increase engagement.

title: USE A NEGATIVE SLANT
description: Negative headlines are clicked on 63% more often than positive ones. Use this to your advantage by testing various negative email subject lines.

title: BITE THE BULLET
description: Did you know that by changing just one bullet point, your conversion rate could increase by 15% or more? Try it!

title: ADJUST THE TIME OF DAY
description: Do more of your customers open emails sent in the morning or the afternoon? Try sending emails out at a few different times throughout the day and see which one gets the best results.

title: PLAY WITH CONTENT
description: Which works best--curated content or original content? Try them both and find out.

title: MOTHER NATURE KNOWS BEST
description: Promote weather-related products based on subscribers’ geographic location. For example, an apparel shop might advertise lightweight jackets in January to Los Angeles, and heavy coats designed for cold climates to New York City.

title: EXPERIMENT WITH FEATURES
description: Wanna know how compelling your feature articles are? Send one feature article to half your subscribers and a different one to the other half. Then, compare engagement rates.

title: COMPARE CONTENT
description: If you offer white papers or webinars, try offering the opposite. You might be surprised by how your recipients respond to a different form of content.

title: ELABORATE WHEN NECESSARY
description: Instead of asking your subscriber to visit your landing page to learn about all of the relevant information, try including most of it inside the actual email (i.e. the date, time, location, and price of the event)

title: VARY THE INTRO LENGTH
description: Which emails work better--those with a short intro or those with a longer intro? Test and see.

title: HOWDY OR HELLO?
description: What greeting works best with your email recipients? Experiment and find out.

title: TALK LOSS
description: People don’t like to lose. Rather than emphasizing a benefit (“do this to gain money”), speak to their fears (“stop losing money”).

title: REDUCE SPAM COMPLAINTS
description: Remind subscribers how and when they signed up for your emails to reduce spam complaints.

title: TRY PRODUCT IMAGE VARIATIONS
description: Better pictures can make a difference. Not sure how great yours are? Try testing various images of your product and see what happens to your conversion rate.

title: CHANGE COLORS
description: Try using different colors in your emails to see which colors generate the greatest amount of enthusiasm--or as we like to call it in marketing, conversions.

title: DON’T BE PHONY
description: Rather than using default stock images of people, try using real pictures instead.

title: HIGHLIGHT SPECIFIC DESIGN ELEMENTS
description: Wanna draw attention to a specific design element? Use a splash of color to draw the eye.

title: MOVE CONTENT AROUND
description: Could the positioning of your content be improved? Try swapping the order of your content categories to find out.

title: MAKE THE OUTCOME CLEAR
description: Is there an image you can use that shows the happy outcome the email recipient will experience if they purchase your product? If the answer is yes, try adding it.

title: DON’T HIDE YOUR HUMOROUS SIDE
description: While serious copy might get the job done, humorous copy can work wonders. Experiment with both to see what your subscribers respond best to.

title: TAKE ADVANTAGE OF TRANSACTIONS
description: Let’s say someone has just completed a purchase with you. Would adding a CTA to your order confirmation email have a positive impact? Try testing various CTAS based on different transactions.

title: CHANGE COLORS
description: Does a different color CTA get more clicks than your current CTA color? Change colors and find out.

title: PERSONALIZE YOUR PITCH
description: Hmmm....why not try adding someone’s name to your CTA button? Pssst, James...Click Here!

title: GO BIG OR GO HOME
description: Is it possible your CTA is too small? Alternatively, maybe it’s larger than it needs to be. Try adjusting its size to see what works best.

title: PLAY WITH POSTSCRIPTS
description: Test the effectiveness of repeating your CTA in the PS vs. putting a 2nd CTA there.

title: INCLUDE IMAGES
description: If you’ve been sending text-only emails, try adding images and see how recipients respond.

title: PRACTICE CONSISTENCY
description: Poorly designed emails tend to use a mix of fonts, graphics, and colors that taken together, create a messy, jarring appearance. Be consistent throughout your email by using the same shapes, colors, fonts, sizes, labels, and type of language.

title: SHOW A REPRESENTATIVE
description: For a personal touch, add an image of one of your call center employees.

title: GO WITH THE GROUP
description: Don’t display a blouse next to gardening tools. Instead, group related items to achieve a cohesive look and feel.

title: REDESIGN YOUR SOCIAL PROOF
description: There are many different ways to design social proof--you can put it in a box, add large quotes around it, change its background color, etc., etc. Try different layouts of your social proof to see which version works best.

title: ADD A BANNER
description: If you haven’t used a banner in an email before, now’s a great time to start. Add one to your next email and see how customers respond.

title: USE VISUAL HIERARCHY
description: Not all elements in an email are of equal importance. Separate important items from less important ones by using visual hierarchy.

title: PERCENTAGES ARE POWERFUL
description: Percentages are another tactic copywriters use to get an audience’s attention. Try putting a percentage in your subject line, then testing your open rates.

title: OFFER OPT-DOWNS
description: Rather than only offering the opportunity to unsubscribe from your mailing list, try adding an opt-down option. Opt-downs allow users to change content preferences and email frequency, meaning you can still maintain a relationship with the subscriber.

title: CHANGE THE TIMING
description: Wanna wow your new email subscribers? You can start by testing the timing of the welcome email they receive.

title: GET STINGY
description: Do you offer discounts in every single email? Try not offering one and see how customers respond.

title: CHANGE IMAGE ALT TEXT
description: Image alt text is the text a user sees when a picture can’t be displayed. Better image alt text will make your emails more user-friendly for those who are visually impaired.

title: REDESIGN SOCIAL
description: Try using a different design for your social buttons to see if your “new look” generates more clicks.

title: DOES SIZE REALLY MATTER?
description: Unfortunately, that’s a question readers need to answer for themselves. Find out by changing the dimensions of your logo and testing.

title: CONSIDER THE HUE OF YOUR HEADER
description: Change the color of your email header and test the impact.

title: MOVE YOUR SOCIAL MEDIA BUTTONS
description: Try changing the location of your social media buttons to see how customers respond.

title: MOVE YOUR LOGO
description: Try testing logo placement to see what impact its location has on conversions.

title: MAKE SEARCHES /SIMPLE
description: Add search box functionality to your email and see how many people take advantage of it.

title: LINK IT
description: Rather than creating new content, try linking to archive and seeing which contents you’ve used in the past generates the greatest interest.

title: ADD AN INDICATOR
description: Consider adding a reading time indicator to articles featured in your emails.

title: DON’T FORGET UPDATES
description: Make sure your content hits the mark by sending an email suggesting subscribers update their content preferences.

title: INCLUDE CAPTIONS
description: Try adding captions to images. If you want, you can even include your CTA within the captions themselves.

title: RESHAPE IT
description: Is the shape of your CTA impacting conversions? Alter it and find out.

title: FIX YOUR FONT
description: San-serif fonts are easier to read than fonts with serifs. If you’re using Times New Roman, for example, try switching to Arial.

title: GO WITH THE FLOW
description: Is there an interesting-looking graph or flow diagram that shows how your product works? Think about incorporating it into a future email.

title: TRY FOOTER NAVIGATION
description: If you’re not currently using footer navigation in your emails, try adding it and analyze the results.

title: GO BIG WITH BENEFITS
description: Rather than creating mind-numbing copy focused on features, emphasize the benefits consumers will experience if they use your solution.

title: RADICALLY REDESIGN
description: A radical redesign can lead to surprising results. Why not have 3 different graphic designers create your landing pages, and then test to see which one is most effective?

title: DON’T BE SHY WITH SCREEN SHOTS
description: If you’re marketing software, use screen shots so prospects have a good idea of how it works.

title: SOCIAL PROOF SELLS
description: Social proof can an effective persuasion tool. If you don’t already have proof on your landing page, add it and see how prospects respond.

title: MOVE OPT-IN FORMS
description: Is your opt-in form below the fold? For optimum results, move it up higher.

title: ADD VIDEO
description: Lots of people find videos very engaging. If you’re not using one on your landing page already, try adding one.

title: MODIFY YOUR MAIN BENEFIT
description: Do you repeatedly tout the same benefit over and over in your headlines? If so, rewrite your headline to focus on a new benefit.

title: GIVE IT AWAY
description: Putting the word “FREE” in your headline is sure to grab prospects’ attention.

title: BE A TEASE
description: Rather than creating a clear headline, why not try a teasing headline that hints at a secret to be solved in the rest of your copy?

title: TAKE IT AWAY
description: By removing navigation from your landing page, you can keep prospects hyper-focused on your CTA.

title: POINT OUT A PAIN
description: By addressing a pain point in your headline (“Are you tired of XYZ?”), you can engage your prospects.

title: OFFER SAMPLES
description: As with bonuses, people enjoy getting free samples. Could you offer 1-3 free samples once someone follows through on your CTA?

title: TEST MOBILITY
description: Try testing 2 versions of your landing page--a mobile-responsive one versus a dedicated mobile site.

title: HONESTY WORKS
description: Creating an (honest) sense of urgency is a great way to persuade consumers to buy (i.e. “Sale ends at midnight!”)

title: VARY RESPONSIVENESS
description: If you haven’t done so already, try testing your landing page on a responsive site versus a non-responsive one.

title: HEAD VS. HEART?
description: Which works better--an intellectual appeal or an emotional one? Try both and see.

title: DETERMINE THE OPTIMAL NUMBER OF LINKS
description: What’s the ideal number of links? Test a landing page with few links versus one with lots of links to find out.

title: USE SCARCITY
description: Scarcity works--try using “Only 2 seats left!” text or whatever makes the most sense in your market.

title: USE A TRIAL
description: Trial memberships are a great tactic for overcoming buyer objections.

title: USE TARGETED CONTENT
description: Is geo-targeted content more impactful than generic content? Test and find out.

title: PICK YOUR PRICE POINT
description: Just as you want to test percent-off discounts to see which is most profitable, you should also do the same with your pricing.

title: APPEAL TO YOUR CUSTOMERS
description: Test two versions of your landing page against each other--one designed for current customers and one designed for non-customers.

title: TO SEGMENT OR NOT TO SEGMENT?
description: What happens when you test a broad offer against an offer segmented toward a specific group of people?

title: OPTIMIZE CODE
description: Does your page load slower than you like? Optimize code and see if people remain on it longer.

title: BE BOLD WITH BULLETS
description: Are you using big blocks of text on your landing pages? Try changing your blocks to bullets.

title: ISOLATE IT
description: Rather than extolling all the features and benefits of your product, write about just one of them.

title: ALTER ALIGNMENT
description: Rather than centering your copy, why not make it left-aligned?

title: DON’T BE DRY
description: Dry text has no appeal. Instead, use conversational, natural language in your copy.

title: TAKE ON TRENDS
description: Take a look at popular trending topics and then, create copy around one of them.

title: GET PERSONAL
description: A personal story or review makes for a highly effective persuasion tactic. Try one in your landing page copy.

title: BE CHOOSY
description: Rather than targeting everyone with your copy, why not identify upfront exactly who your solution is for?

title: FORGET FACTS
description: Instead of listing facts, why not try creating a story about your product?

title: PLAY WITH LENGTH
description: What’s the perfect amount of copy? Find out by testing short copy against longer copy.

title: BECOME MORE CREDIBLE
description: If you typically use a lot of hyperbole in your ads, switch your copy up by offering facts and figures, rather than hype.

title: SWITCH THE “SELL”
description: Do you typically use a hard sell or a soft sell? Try doing the opposite and see what happens to conversions.

title: ANALYZE YOUR BULLETS
description: If your bullet points contain a list of features, try creating super-specific benefit-rich bullets instead.

title: JUST MOVE IT
description: Is your CTA in the perfect position? Try moving it around to find its ideal location.

title: WATCH THE CLOCK
description: How does adding a countdown timer to your landing page affect sales? Test and find out.

title: FIND YOUR FOCUS
description: Instead of using lots of links on your landing pages, why not minimize links so users are hyper-focused on your CTA?

title: BE SELECTIVE
description: Offering consumers too much choice can hurt sales, rather than help. If you have a number of different options on your landing page, try eliminating some of them to increase conversions.

title: GET REAL (OR NOT)
description: Are photos of real people more effective than stock photos? Try both and see.

title: VARY YOUR COLUMNS
description: Are you using a single column or multiple columns? Whatever your answer, try using more (or less) columns and test the results.

title: SCRAP AN IMAGE
description: Your landing page may experience higher conversions if you scrap an image, replacing it with a video.

title: CHANGE THE SCENERY
description: Is your background imagery helping or hindering conversions? Try switching it up to see if a different background is more effective.

title: USE YOUR AMBASSADORS
description: Do you use brand ambassadors or spokespeople? If so, try adding images of them to your landing page.

title: BUILD ENGAGEMENT
description: A quiz or a poll on your landing page is a great way to build engagement.

title: TRY A POP-UP
description: A triggered pop-up may increase conversions.

title: SHOW THE OUTCOME
description: Rather than merely mentioning the outcome users will experience with your product, why not show a picture of a user EXPERIENCING that outcome?

title: MIND OVER MATTER
description: Mind maps are diagrams representing tasks or concepts related to a specific subject. Consider using them--or hand-drawn illustrations--on your landing page.

title: ANCHOR YOUR PRICE
description: Instead of merely listing your price, anchor it. For example, you might show a suggested retail price of $49 crossed out, and next to it include the actual price of $29.

title: ADJUST YOUR HEADLINE HEIGHT
description: A larger--or smaller--headline may have a favorable impact on conversions.

title: ADD A CONVERSION PATH
description: Do you have a number of different audiences that could benefit from copy specifically geared toward their interests? If your answer is yes, try creating a landing page with buttons that allow visitors to choose their specific areas of interest. For example, a college landing page might include links for prospective students, current students, and parents.

title: IT’S MAGNIFICENT, DAHLING
description: Big bold adjectives and adverbs in a headline are compelling. Try using words like remarkable, amazing, groundbreaking, etc.

title: BONUSES ARE BIG
description: People love bonuses. If you don’t offer one on your landing page already, add one and see how it impacts conversions.

title: OFFER A RECOMMENDATION
description: If you’re offering multiple products or packages, try making a recommendation to prospects.

title: CALCULATE REDEMPTION TIME
description: If you’re offering a flash sale, why not test two different redemption times against each other?

title: COMMITMENT IS SCARY
description: Rather than expecting users to make an annual commitment, for example, try a quarterly or monthly commitment instead.

title: SHIPPING SHOWDOWN
description: Which works best--offering free shipping or a % off discount? Try both and see.

title: USE DIFFERENT DISCOUNTS
description: How many conversions do you get with a 20% discount? What about a 40% one? Test different percentage-off discounts to see which is most profitable.

title: 14-DAYS VS. 30-DAYS?
description: When people have 30 days to test something, they don’t feel a sense of urgency. If you’re offering a free trial on your landing page, why not try making it a 14-day one?

title: CHANGE YOUR PERSPECTIVE
description: If you’re writing with a he/she/we/you perspective, try switching perspectives.

title: WHAT’S WITH WHY?
description: Typically, copywriters create a narrative around why someone needs a product or service. Create copy around multiple why’s and test to see which works best.

title: USE LOSS AVERSION
description: People hate to lose. Rather than focusing on all they’ll gain by using your product, create copy around averting loss (“Do XYZ to avoid losing money!”)

title: TALK BUCKS
description: Are you giving something free away? Don’t be shy--let your audience know exactly how much it’s worth.

title: RECOMMEND ITEMS
description: If you’re selling multiple items, try recommending specific items to consumers. For bonus points, test recommendation algorithms against each other.

title: USE CLICK INDICATORS
description: The better your design is, the higher your conversions will be. To enhance your design, consider adding click indicators to your CTA.

title: ALTER CTA COLOR
description: Does the color of your CTA hurt or help your sales message? Try testing a few different colors to find out.

title: THINK OUTSIDE THE BOX
description: Rather than using the standard “Click Here Now” CTA, why not get creative and use text that’s a bit more unusual?

title: KEEP ‘EM FROM FORGETTING
description: If you have a lengthy landing page, why not try using a CTA that scrolls along with your users?

title: TOSS THE TASKS
description: Instead of a task-oriented CTA (“Click Here”), try a benefit-based CTA (i.e. “I Want to Save $$$ Now!”)

title: USE REPETITION
description: If 1 CTA button is good, are 3 CTA buttons better? Try repeating your CTA multiple times throughout your landing page to see how sales are affected.

title: PUT OUT FEELERS
description: Get a feel for which landing page design works best--one with a campaign-specific look and feel versus one with a brand-specific look and feel.

title: CREATE A LANDING PAGE CONSISTENT WITH YOUR AD
description: Rather than creating a landing page that looks nothing like the ad someone clicked to reach it, aim for consistent images and copy.

title: TRY A PRE-HEADER
description: Rather than launching right into your headline, try adding pre-header text to see how prospects respond.

title: CONSISTENCY ALSO WORKS WITHIN THE LANDING PAGE
description: Colors, directions, behaviors, positions, sizes, shapes, labels, and language--these elements all work together to create the overall look and feel of your landing page. For maximum effectiveness, make sure these elements are consistent throughout your entire page.

title: MOVE TESTIMONIALS
description: Should your testimonials be placed higher on the page? Closer to your CTA? Try moving testimonials around to find the best location for them.

title: GO PRO
description: Do you have professional photos of your deliverables on your landing page? If not, add them and see how visitors respond.

title: USE CAMOUFLAGE
description: What happens if you redesign your landing page so it looks less like an ad? Try it and find out.

title: MULTIPLY YOUR PRODUCTS (OR DON’T)
description: What works best--featuring one product on your landing page or multiple products? Test different versions of your landing page to find out.

title: GET PERSONAL BASED ON PROFILE
description: If you have prospects’ profile information, try showing them personalized images based on their profiles.

title: ELIMINATE DISTRACTIONS
description: Too many borders and boxes distract from your sales message. If your landing page is visually busy, try eliminating some of these elements.

title: TRANSFORM YOUR BACKGROUND
description: Using a photo as your landing page background may be more impactful than just a plain background. Try both and see which works best.

title: DON’T BE FAKE
description: Video fakeouts are elements that function like videos but aren’t actual videos. If you’re using fakeouts, try eliminating them.

title: CHART IT
description: An interesting-looking flowchart is a great way to capture prospects’ interest.

title: CREATE COMBINATIONS
description: Do some products you sell naturally complement each other? Try combining them into packages.

title: CONVERT THE FONT
description: By changing your headline’s font, does your landing page get better results?

title: GET LENGTH RIGHT
description: Is a short landing page or a longer one more effective for your brand? Try both and see.

title: ALTER THE LENGTH
description: Does your headline use too much text or not enough? Test shorter and longer headlines to find out.

title: BE A LITTLE WEIRD
description: The best copywriters know that oddly specific numbers in a headline work. If you’re not using this tactic already, give it a try.

title: JUST ASK
description: Questions work well in headlines. Rather than merely stating facts in your headline, try asking a question instead.

title: PERCENTAGES ARE POWERFUL
description: Oddly specific numbers in a headline aren’t the only numbers that grab prospects’ attention--percentages do as well.

title: BE A MINIMALIST
description: Rather than creating extra pages, try merging your signup page and landing page.

title: TRY PERSONAL PRONOUNS
description: Personal pronouns (he, she, we, you) can be compelling--include them in your headline and test the results.

title: SAY THANKS
description: Once users act on your CTA, try a thank you page with a new CTA, suggesting they leave a review or share their purchase on social media.

title: PUT OTHERS FIRST
description: Rather than tooting your own horn (“We’re the best!”), try focusing on your customers’ needs (“You deserve the best!”)

title: JUST CUT IT
description: Does your copy tend to ramble? Create super-concise copy with short paragraphs and simple phrasing.

title: FLY THE FREEDOM FLAG
description: A clever copywriting tactic is to remind customers that it’s their choice to buy--they’re free to refuse.

title: DON’T BEAT AROUND THE BUSH
description: Rather than being wishy-washy with your copy (“If you want to...”), be very direct (“Click here now.”).

title: PLAY WITH URGENCY
description: Some urgent appeals are more successful than others. Try testing various urgent appeals to see which works best for your brand.

title: PLEASED TO MEET YOU
description: Introduce yourself or your product by name, with a photo, or through an origin story. Copy with personality typically fares better than more generic copy.

title: MIX UP CONTENT
description: If you’re offering free content like an e-book, try switching things up by promoting a webinar instead.

title: ALTER A LONE BULLET
description: Changing just ONE bullet can have a big impact on conversions. Try altering one of yours and see!

title: EMBRACE ILLUSIONS
description: Price illusions are super-effective at showing consumers an item’s true value. For instance, if you’re selling software, you might say something like, “You pay just .15 per template!”

title: CHANGE YOUR NAME
description: Think your product could get higher sales if only it had a better name? Try testing 2 names against each other on your landing pages.

title: LET BONUSES GO HEAD-TO-HEAD
description: Why not try testing 2 different bonuses against each other?

title: CELEBRATE!
description: If you have a special event coming up, create copy around it and do some testing.

title: EVERYONE APPRECIATES HUMOR
description: Rather than being overly serious, try peppering your copy with humor.

title: DIRECT EYES TO YOUR CTA
description: Are you using visual cues to draw prospects’ attention to your CTA? If not, add some directional arrows or other cues to get your CTA noticed.

title: USE IMAGES CREATIVELY
description: What would happen if you added CTAs to product images? Test and find out.

title: SWAP IT
description: Should you swap the order of items on your landing page? Move content around and test the results.

title: SWITCH LINKS UP
description: Could the order of your links and CTA be impacting sales? Probably. To determine whether the impact is a positive or a negative one, switch the order of your CTA and links.

title: ANIMATE IT
description: If you’re not using animated gifs, add one to your landing page and see how users react.

title: GRAB ATTENTION
description: Are you getting your main points across? If your answer is no, add directional arrows and irregular shapes that draw prospects’ eyes to critically important copy.

title: DON’T CONFUSE CUSTOMERS
description: If you’re using tables on your landing page to compare various products, make sure they’re user-friendly i.e. easy-to-understand.

title: REDESIGN YOUR SOCIAL PROOF
description: There are plenty of different ways you can display social proof--with large quotes around it, in a bordered box, italicized, etc. Experiment with the way you display social proof on your landing page to see which design works best.

title: ORGANIZE ITEMS
description: Group related items on your landing page together, rather than displaying them haphazardly.

title: ADD VISUAL APPEAL
description: Adding a photo to the form on your landing page may increase conversions.

title: THE EYES HAVE IT
description: What happens when you use images of people looking directly at your CTA? Add them and find out.

title: JUST ADD PEOPLE
description: Which works best--images of your product by itself or images of people using your product? Test both versions and find out.

title: USE COLOR AS A HIGHLIGHTER
description: Color presents an excellent way to highlight a specific element on your landing page.

title: CORRECT COLORS
description: Colors impact the entire look and feel of a landing page. See how effective your current colors are by testing them against new ones.

title: REDUCE COPY ON IMAGES
description: Rather than using copy-heavy images, try replacing them with images that use little copy.

title: VARY IMAGE DEMOGRAPHICS
description: Images present plenty of testing opportunities. Try testing them using different ages, genders, and by altering the number of people in the photos.

title: MINIMIZE YOUR DESIGN
description: A design that appears overly busy probably isn’t doing your business any favors. Try minimizing your design and see what happens.

title: LET ‘EM READ!
description: While plenty of people enjoy videos, there are still a number of avid readers who prefer written text. If you currently use video on your landing page, try testing it against a white paper.

title: MAKE A MERGE
description: Try merging similar functionality on your landing page to give it a streamlined appearance. For example, “Contact Us” and “Customer Service” links could easily be merged into just one link.

title: CLARITY COUNTS
description: Don’t be visually ambiguous. Try altering your landing page to very clearly display the difference between elements on the page.

title: DITCH Y-AXIS JUMPS
description: Y-axis jumps occur when people click links on a page and are then taken to a new vertical location on that same page. If you’re using them currently, try removing them to see how your prospects respond.

title: HIERARCHY HELPS
description: Make the most important items on your page visually distinct from those that are less important.

title: DO SOMETHING UNEXPECTED
description: Do you offer the same deals over and over again? Brainstorm and come up with something unexpected.

title: REPOSITION PRICING
description: Does your price appear below the fold? Move it higher!

title: USE SAN-SERIF
description: San-serif font is easier to read than a serif font like Times New Roman. If you’re using serifs, switch to a san-serif font and test.

title: MAKE COMMITMENTS EASY
description: Try offering social commitments if you aren’t already. By allowing users to share on Facebook that they bought a certain item, for example, you’ll benefit from free publicity.

title: REDESIGN SOCIAL BUTTONS
description: Are the social buttons on your landing page being overlooked? Try redesigning them.

title: SWITCH SHAPES
description: Change the shape of your CTA to see which button shape is most attention-grabbing.

title: RELOCATE SOCIAL
description: Are your social buttons ideally positioned? Try moving them around to see if a new location yields more clicks.

title: VARY IT UP
description: Are there some images of your products that generate higher sales than other images? Vary product pictures to see.

title: CHANGE TAKES TIME
description: Sometimes the best way to engage prospects is to hook them gradually. Rather than asking them to give their email address immediately, why not reel them in slowly? For example, a furniture store might ask prospects to select their decorating style BEFORE asking for an email address.

title: USE A FOOTER
description: If you’re not using footer navigation, try adding it or vice versa.

title: MIND OVER MATTER
description: Mind maps are diagrams representing tasks or concepts related to a specific subject. Consider incorporating them--or hand-drawn illustrations--into your graphics and videos.

title: GET REAL (OR NOT)
description: Do stock photos work better or do images of real people sell more? Try both and see.

title: SHOW OR TELL?
description: Which video gets more conversions--an informational one or a demonstration? Test each version and see.

title: REMOVE VIDEO FAKEOUTS
description: Video fakeouts are elements that function like videos but aren’t actual videos. If you’re using fakeouts, try eliminating them.

title: DOES FORMALITY WORK?
description: Try testing professional photos vs. more casual, laidback photos.

title: LET ‘EM READ!
description: Not everyone enjoys videos. Try appealing to those individuals by giving them the opportunity to read text, rather than watch a video.

title: DISPLAY THE DESIRED OUTCOME
description: Rather than merely mentioning the outcome users will experience with your product, why not show a picture of a user EXPERIENCING that outcome?

title: REIMAGINE IMAGES
description: Are you relying heavily on product images in your videos? Try using more people images or vice versa.

title: FORGO THE USUAL FONTS
description: Why not try creating 2 videos--one with san-serif text and one without?

title: USE THUMBNAILS
description: Are you using video thumbnails? If not, try creating some to see if more people opt to watch your videos.

title: BE RESPONSIVE
description: Try testing a mobile-responsive site against a mobile stand-alone site to see which one users prefer.

title: ARE ICONS INVALUABLE?
description: Which works best--icons or plain text? Try both to find out which option is truly invaluable.

title: VARY LENGTH
description: What’s the optimum length of a mobile page? Test various lengths to find out.

title: NAVIGATE YOUR OPTIONS
description: There are three main ways to display navigation choices on a mobile page: blinds, buttons, and blocks. Try experimenting with all three to determine which works best for your mobile site.

title: TALK ABOUT TABLET OPTIMIZATION
description: Plenty of businesses send tablet users to mobile versions of their websites. However, a tablet-friendly site may be an even better bet.

title: SWITCH UP YOUR ICONS
description: Which leads to more engagement--a hamburger icon, text with the word, “MENU,” or some combination of both? Try them all and see.

title: OPTIMIZE FOR OPERATING SYSTEM
description: If you’re not doing so already, target mobile users by operating system to see if doing so increases conversions.

title: USE FRIENDLY FILTERS
description: Filtering and sorting can be cumbersome on mobile sites. Try testing various filtering/sorting options to increase the user-friendliness of your site.

title: RING THE ALARM
description: Emphasize to prospects why they must ACT NOW by creating a sense of urgency (sale ends at midnight)! However, don’t lie--you’ll lose credibility with consumers.

title: USE SCARCITY
description: Scarcity works--try using “Only 2 seats left!” text or whatever makes the most sense in your market.

title: HAVE A CONVERSATION
description: Avoid boring prospects to tears with dry, overly serious copy. Instead, imagine a conversation you’d have with a friend and create your copy based on that.

title: BE BIG ON BENEFITS
description: Features don’t sell--benefits do. Rather than including a list of features in your ad, try focusing on the benefits your customers will experience.

title: GET PERSONAL
description: A personal story or review is a highly effective persuasion tactic.

title: DON’T SIT ON THE FENCE
description: Hesitancy doesn’t generate sales. Instead, use direct language (“Click here now!”).

title: PROVE IT
description: People are much more likely to buy something if they think, “Everybody’s doing it.” Try running ads with social proof (over 10,000 users) and without to test its effect.

title: CONSISTENCY ON THE CLICK
description: When someone clicks on your CTA, are they taken to a landing page that doesn’t resemble your ad at all? Try changing the design on your landing page so its appearance is consistent with your Facebook ad.

title: TESTIMONIALS ARE TOPS
description: Testimonials make for a very effective marketing tool. Add testimonials to your ads to see how they impact sales.

title: GET REAL (OR NOT)
description: Try testing photos of real people against stock photos.

title: DOUBLE YOUR ODDS
description: Are 2 CTAs better than just 1? Find out by putting a CTA in your body copy AND your imagery.

title: WHAT ABOUT VIDEO?
description: If you’re not using video yet, test how a video ad fares against one without.

title: EMPHASIZE A DIFFERENT BENEFIT
description: Have you been relying on headlines that mention the same benefit over and over again? Get creative and write a headline that promotes a completely different benefit.

title: REDESIGN YOUR LANDING PAGE
description: Try testing 2 completely different versions of landing pages against each other.

title: FREE WORKS
description: The word “FREE” is a captivating one. Use it in your headline to see how your audience reacts.

title: BONUSES ARE BENEFICIAL
description: Bonuses can be very compelling to consumers. Add a bonus to one of your FB ads and test the results.

title: SHOW YOU CARE
description: Rather than creating ads that talk about how great your company is, try writing an ad that emphasizes the great experience the USERS will have with your company.

title: GIVE SAMPLES
description: Samples give consumers yet another incentive to buy while introducing your customers to new products. Consider promoting the free samples you offer with every purchase.

title: BE UPFRONT WITH PRICING
description: Does putting your price in the ad increase sales? Test and find out.

title: EXPERIMENT WITH SEGMENTING
description: Does a segmented offer for a specific audience outperform a broader offer? Try both and see.

title: LET USERS TRY IT
description: Trial memberships are a great tactic for overcoming buyer objections.

title: VARY OCPM TESTING
description: oCPM is Facebook’s most versatile bidding option. With oCPM, advertisers can use FB’s algorithms to optimize for the following goals: user actions, reach, clicks, or social impressions. Do some experimenting to see which works bests for your campaign.

title: TEST BIDDING
description: Facebook offers 4 different bidding types: cost per click (CPC), cost per thousand impressions (CPM), optimized CPM (oCPM), and cost per action (CPA). Try testing all 4 to see which works best for your brand.

title: ALTER AGE
description: Have all of your ads been directed at a targeted age group? Try advertising toward a new age group and see what happens.

title: TRY A NEW TYPE
description: Facebook offers a multitude of ad types including canvas, collection, carousel, etc. Experiment with different ad types to see which works best for your brand.

title: ALTER EDUCATION LEVEL
description: Try targeting audiences by their educational status, a specific degree, or the college they attended.

title: GO INTERNATIONAL
description: Split testing Facebook ads by countries has been shown to offer a high return on investment (ROI).

title: APPEAL TO INTERESTS
description: Facebook has an unbelievable amount of data about its users. Use that to your advantage by trying interest-based segmentation.

title: CUSTOMIZE
description: Facebook allows businesses to create Custom Audiences, audiences made up of a subset of your current customers, like your Facebook or Instagram followers. Experiment with Custom Audiences to see which audience delivers the best results.

title: GO AFTER GENDERS
description: Do you think your product is more appealing to one gender than another? Try testing ads geared toward men or women only.

title: REASSURE, REASSURE, REASSURE
description: It’s always a great idea to reassure your customers (shhh... everything’s going to be ok) with text like: no risk, cancel any time, secure checkout, etc.

title: BE SELECTIVE
description: Rather than trying to be all things to all people, create copy saying exactly who your solution is for.

title: AVERT A CRISIS
description: Rather than emphasizing gains (“Act now if you want to make money!”), use a nifty little tactic called loss aversion (“Act now to avoid losing all your money!”)

title: MIX IT UP
description: What works better--lots of copy or just a little? Try testing both to see.

title: RETHINK YOUR WHY
description: Think of several reasons why someone needs your product--then, create copy around each of your responses and test.

title: FOREGO THE HYPE
description: While hype can work sometimes, facts and figures may do an even better job of persuading your audience.

title: BE CONCISE
description: There’s probably plenty of things you’d like to say about your product. Rather than trying to fit it all in, see how effective concise copy is.

title: ALTER PLACEMENT
description: Facebook allows businesses to place ads in a variety of places--News Feeds, groups, the right column, and as Instant Articles. Try a multitude of placements to test what works best for your brand.

title: PEPPER YOUR AD WITH PERSONALITY
description: Generic copy is dull. Create copy with personality instead.

title: MIX IT UP
description: What works better--lots of copy or just a little? Try testing both to see.

title: EXPERIMENT WITH CTA COPY
description: Try testing different CTA text (i.e. “Click Here” vs. “Learn More”).

title: CHANGE COLORS
description: Colors are great to test. Try switching up the colors of your FB ad to find out which color is most effective.

title: TO TEXT OR NOT TO TEXT?
description: Could a textual ad be more impactful than an image-based ad? Try them both.

title: CUT YOUR HEADLINE COPY
description: Are you using a long headline? Chop it and use a shorter one--or vice versa.

title: ATTRACT ATTENTION WITH A TEASE
description: A teasing headline hints at a mystery. Rather than creating a clear headline, drop a hint about your product in the headline and watch what happens to your conversion rate.

title: USE GREAT DESCRIPTORS
description: Strong adjectives and adverbs in your headline can pack a punch. Try using words like remarkable, sensational, startling, quick, easy, etc.

title: PESSIMISM = SALES
description: Headlines that focus on the negative typically get better results than more upbeat headlines. Try both and see.

title: GET ODDLY SPECIFIC
description: For some reason, oddly specific numbers are very effective. Use them in your headline for maximum benefit.

title: PERCENTAGES ARE POWERFUL
description: Percentages are another tactic copywriters use to get an audience’s attention. Try putting a percentage in your headline to increase clicks.

title: VARY YOUR DISCOUNTS
description: How many people click your CTA when you offer a 20% discount? What about a 33% discount? Try experimenting with your discounts to see which offer is most profitable.

title: PACK YOUR HEADLINE WITH POWER
description: Look online and you’ll find dozens of websites with lists of the most powerful words in copywriting. Try incorporating some of these words into your headline.

title: TRIAL LENGTH SHOWDOWN
description: If you typically advertise 30-day free trials, try testing a shorter trial to see how people respond.

title: REINVENT INCENTIVES
description: If you’re offering free content like an e-book, try switching things up by promoting a webinar instead.

title: TEST SHIPPING VS. DISCOUNTS
description: Which sells better--free shipping or a percentage-off discount? Try both and see.

title: USE RELATIONSHIP STATUS
description: Try testing your ads based on people’s relationship status.

title: USE A POINTED GAZE
description: A pair of eyes gazing directly at your CTA may generate more clicks.

title: GO AFTER TECHIES
description: Run a test geared toward early vs. late technology adopters to see which audience yields a higher conversion rate.

title: LOSE THE LOGO
description: If you already have a logo in your ad, try removing it. Alternatively, if you’re not using a logo, add one and see what happens.

title: USE URGENCY
description: Try testing various urgent appeals. For instance, you might run 1 ad with a countdown timer and another ad with text that reads, “Don’t wait! Sale ends at midnight.”

title: TRY DIFFERENT LOOKS
description: Which makes for a more effective ad--a campaign-specific look and feel or a brand-specific one? Try both and see.

title: ASK AND YOU SHALL RECEIVE
description: A question in the headline makes for a great way to capture people’s attention.

title: USE ANCHORING
description: Rather than just showing your actual price of $99, why not display that number next to a crossed-out suggested retail price of $199?

title: PUT A HA-HA IN YOUR HEADLINE
description: Funny or clever headlines can work wonders!

title: TO CODE OR NOT TO CODE?
description: Which is more effective--offering a coupon code in your ad or directing prospects to a landing page where the discount’s already been applied?

title: GET PERSONAL
description: Personal pronouns (he, she, we, you) can be compelling--include them in your headline and test the results.

title: USE ILLUSIONS
description: Price illusions are super-effective at showing consumers an item’s true value. For instance, if you’re selling software, you might say something like, “You pay just .15 per template!”

title: SWITCH UP BRANDS
description: If you’re not already, try running tests aimed at mobile device users based on their brand.

title: CONTEST IT!
description: A contest or prize draw can be very appealing to prospects.

title: USE OS
description: Run tests aimed at users of various mobile operating systems to see how they fare against each other.

title: USE PRO PHOTOS
description: Professional photos of your deliverables can inspire users to click on your CTA.

title: TRY BEHAVIOR TESTING
description: Facebook allows you to do very specific segmenting. Wanna run tests based on user behaviors? There are plenty of different ones you can choose from.

title: EXPERIMENT WITH IMAGES
description: Which works best--a single image or multiple images? Test and see.

title: HOHOHO...THE HOLIDAYS ARE HERE
description: Seasonal ad copy can be very impactful, particularly if your sales tend to spike at certain times of the year.

title: UGLIFY IT
description: Ironically, some ugly ads outperform more professionally-done ads. Try creating one to see if you have the same experience.

title: WATCH THE CLOCK
description: Time-sensitive offers force prospects to make a quick decision about a purchase they’re considering--creating this sense of urgency is often to a marketer’s benefit.

title: PLAY WITH SPACE
description: Which works best--using all of the space in your ad or leaving lots of extra space?

title: ...DON’T FORGET
description: It’s super-important to use CTAs. If you don’t have one in your PPC ad already, add one!

title: BE NOSY
description: Putting a question in the headline is a great way to engage your audience.

title: LESS LENGTH?
description: Would your headline be more effective if it was shorter or longer? Try both and see.

title: BE DEDICATED
description: Rather than sending prospects to your home page when they click your PPC, why not try taking them to a dedicated landing page instead?

title: USE SELECTIVITY
description: Try saying in your headline exactly who your solution is for, rather than trying to be all things to all people.

title: PUT FORTH YOUR PRICE
description: Overcome buyer reluctance by stating your price upfront in the ad.

title: USE THE WORD, “FREE”
description: The word “free” has a special ability to make people take notice. Add it to one of your headlines and see for yourself.

title: ANIMATION IS APPEALING
description: Could your static PPC ad get more clicks if you animated it? Try it and find out.

title: GET CREATIVE
description: There are a number of different animation styles--like roll, wipe, and replace--that could improve your banner ad’s conversion rates.

title: USE A USP
description: A USP is marketing-speak for Unique Selling Proposition. Essentially, it’s what makes your brand different (and better) than the competition. For example, FedEx’s USP was once: “When it absolutely, positively has to be there overnight.”

title: TALK COLD HARD CASH
description: Are you promoting a free gift in your ad? Mention exactly how much that free gift is worth to add value to your offer.

title: USE “COPYWRITER-APPROVED” WORDS
description: Copywriters love words like tips, strategies, and lessons. Why? Because they get clicks. Try adding one of them to your ad.

title: ACT REBELLIOUSLY
description: Are your competitors all doing the same thing? Do the opposite.

title: USE SOCIAL PROOF
description: Do you have 10,000 customers already? Then, say so--don’t be shy about letting prospects know how popular your business is.

title: ALTER YOUR QSP
description: QSP is an acronym for quality, selection, and pricing. Try changing these items in your copy to discover which version of your ad is most successful.

title: INCORPORATE A QUIZ
description: Quizzes are a compelling way of grabbing prospects’ attention. Consider promoting an interesting quiz to get people to click over to your landing page.

title: ANSWER FOUR QUESTIONS
description: Try testing the who/what/why/how of your ad copy by asking yourself (1) who’s my target audience? (2) what do they want? (3) why do they want it? and (4) how would they like to get it? Use your answers to create different versions of copy to test.

title: INCORPORATE INTRIGUE
description: Intriguing words like weird, unusual, and odd are real attention-grabbers.

title: KEEP CREDIBILITY IN MIND
description: Rather than using lots of hype (i.e. marvelous, sensational, groundbreaking), try adding specific facts and figures to your ad to improve your credibility.

title: TRY DYNAMIC KEYWORD INSERTION
description: Dynamic Keyword Insertion allows you to alter your ad copy based on a searcher’s query. For instance, if someone searched for a lawnmower, that word would appear in the copy; likewise, if the search was for gardening supplies, that’s the phrase that would appear.

title: TRY DIFFERENT PHRASING
description: Is your CTA as impactful as it could be? Change its phrasing to see.

title: TUG AT PEOPLE’S HEARTSTRINGS
description: Why not try an emotional appeal by using emoticons or a meme in your ad?

title: ADJUST YOUR BACKGROUND
description: You can experience surprising results, just by changing the background color of your ad.

title: TEASE ‘EM
description: Teasing headlines hint at a mystery to be solved--this time-honored tactic is used by some of the world’s greatest copywriters.

title: WHOA...IT’S TOO BRIGHT
description: Is your ad overly bright or not bright enough? Try adjusting its color vibrance to find out.

title: BE CONSIDERATE
description: Rather than creating a headline that’s all about your company (“We’re the best.”), why not try creating one that puts your customers first (“You deserve the best.”)?

title: SHOW STRENGTH
description: Strong adjectives and adverbs in a headline can increase clicks.

title: PERCENTAGES ARE POWERFUL
description: Percentages are also attention-grabbers. Try putting one into your headline to get prospects’ notice.

title: USE YOUR POWER VOCAB
description: Emergency! New! Cheap! Fast! These are all powerful words to add to any headline.

title: OPT TO GIVE A DISCOUNT
description: If you’re not using discounts, offering one may be the way to go.

title: THERE’S STRENGTH IN NUMBERS
description: Oddly specific numbers appeal to prospects. Put one in your headline and see for yourself.

title: OFFER A TRIAL
description: A trial membership is a great way to appeal to prospects who are on the fence about purchasing.

title: 14-DAYS VS. 30-DAYS?
description: If your ad promotes a free trial, try making it a shorter trial (14 days) rather than a longer one (30 days) to create a sense of urgency.

title: LET SOMEONE TESTIFY
description: A short testimonial is a great way to add persuasive appeal to your ad.

title: SELECT A SUBFOLDER
description: If you’re not using a subfolder for your display URL already, why not try adding one and testing the results? For example, instead of using a link like www.GreatBooks.com, try www.GreatBooks.com/BestSellers.

title: DISPLAY SYMBOLS
description: Add a copyright and/or trademark symbol to your ad to see how it impacts conversions.

title: ADD A SUBDOMAIN
description: Another great testing idea is to try using a subdomain while keeping your destination URL the same. For example, you might try using a URL like the following: BestSellers.GreatBooks.com

title: CHANGE WORD ORDER
description: Could your copy benefit from being rearranged? Try changing its order to see how prospects respond.

title: CHANGE COLORS
description: If you change the color of your CTA, does your ad get more clicks? Try it and find out.

title: COLOR YOUR FONT
description: Red, green, blue, yellow, or orange font colors can capture the attention of your prospects.

title: ALTER BORDER COLORS
description: If you’re not using a pink, aqua blue, purple, orange, yellow, green, or red border, why not? Just kidding, but seriously--a different border color may draw more attention to your ad.

title: TALK LOSS
description: Rather than emphasizing gains (“Do this to earn money”), create a headline around loss aversion (“Do this to avoid losing money.”).

title: REDESIGN YOUR BORDER
description: Could a solid, dashed, or dotted border line yield more clicks for your ad?

title: ? OR !
description: Which is more engaging--? or !? Try testing a question mark in a headline against a headline with an exclamation point.

title: CHANGE YOUR LANDING PAGE
description: Does changing your landing page increase conversions? Try it and find out.

title: USE CAPITALIZATION
description: What Happens When You Capitalize Each Word Of Copy In Your Ad?

title: DISCOUNTS VARIATIONS ARE DELIGHTFUL
description: Rather than relying on the same discount you always use, why not test various discounts against each other to see which is most profitable?

title: PRACTICE CONSISTENCY
description: Rather than using one sales message in your headline and an unrelated one in your body copy, keep your message consistent.

title: TRY VARIOUS SHIPPING OPTIONS
description: Which is most profitable--offering free shipping or charging a fee for shipping? Test both and see.

title: VARY WORD LENGTH
description: Which generates higher conversions--ads peppered with long words or ads that use shorter ones? Try both.

title: JUST SAY “YOUR” OR “MINE”
description: Both of these words add personal appeal and have been shown to increase conversions. Try adding one of them to your ad copy.

title: CAPITALIZE THE URL
description: What about using a URL that’s in all-caps? WWW.GREATBOOKS.COM

title: ADD AUTHORITY
description: Authority graphics--like an iTunes logo--can increase an ad’s credibility factor.

title: GET REAL
description: Try using real people in your PPC ad, rather than stock photos.

title: SWITCH BACKGROUND SHAPES
description: Rather than using a plain background, why not try adding shapes--for example, squares, circles, or triangles--in subtle hues to the background?

title: SHOW THE OUTCOME
description: Can you create an image of the outcome prospects will experience if they buy your product? If so, try adding the image to your ad.

title: COPY THE BEST
description: There are plenty of popular brands that have certain colors associated with them--Facebook, Twitter, UPS, etc. Why not try using the same color scheme that one of the big brands is using?

title: HAHAS HELP
description: Most people find humorous ad copy more engaging than serious copy. Try adding some humor to your ad copy.

title: USE CAPITALIZATION
description: What Happens If You Capitalize Each Word In Your Headline?

title: ADD QUOTATIONS
description: Is there a particular quotation that sums up the appeal of your brand or product? Use it in your copy.

title: CHANNEL YOUR INNER POET
description: Try creating a rhyming ad--copy that grabs attention is great, it positively impacts conversion rates!

title: ADD THE WWW
description: If you’re not using www in your ad, try adding it and then, analyze the results.

title: CHANGE YOUR FONT
description: Is your font helping or hindering your ad? Generally speaking, san-serif fonts tend to get better results. If you’re not using one, why not try creating an ad in Arial?

title: TRY IRREGULAR PUNCTUATION
description: Irregular punctuation is an attention-grabber. Why. not. try. using. odd. punctuation. in. your. headline?

title: ALLITERATE, ALLITERATE, ALLITERATE!
description: Alliteration is a sentence where every word begins with the same letter: Apples Are Amazing! Try this tactic with your headline.

title: ADD A BONUS
description: Bonuses are in a word--COMPELLING. Try adding one to your video sales letter to see your conversions improve.

title: TAKE AWAY CONTROL
description: Want to make sure someone gleans the main points of your video? Consider removing video controls so users can’t fast-forward.

title: PLAY WITH LENGTH
description: Is your video too short or too long? Try creating another video of a different length to find out.

title: VARY VOICES
description: Which works best for your video--a male voiceover or a female voiceover? Try both and see.

title: TO AUTOPLAY OR NOT TO AUTOPLAY?
description: Which works best--a click-to-play video or one that uses autoplay? Try both and see.

title: GO EASY ON THE HYPE
description: While hype has its place (i.e. magnificent, jaw-dropping, groundbreaking), try replacing it with facts and figures to increase your credibility.

title: PULL THE TRIGGER
description: Time-triggered CTAs remain invisible until the perfect time. If you’re not using one already, give this tactic a try.

title: TRIAL LENGTH SHOWDOWN
description: Which works best--a 14-day trial or a 30-day trial? Surprisingly, one company found that shorter trials were more effective. Test to see if that holds true for your company.

title: SWITCH YOUR MVP
description: Your MVP--or main value proposition--might benefit from a change. Try switching it up to see if another MVP works better.

title: GET LOOK AND FEEL RIGHT
description: Should your video resemble the look and feel of your brand or would a campaign-specific look be more impactful?

title: LOAD A LETTER
description: Not everyone enjoys watching videos. With this in mind, try loading a long-form sales letter at the same time your CTA becomes visible.

title: SHOW THE DESIRED OUTCOME
description: Rather than merely mentioning the outcome users will experience with your product, why not show a picture of a user EXPERIENCING that outcome?

title: TELL ‘EM WHAT IT COSTS
description: Are you offering a free gift that has a substantial value? Don’t be shy--let your audience know the value of your free gift.

title: PAUSE IT
description: Worried that users might open new tabs and begin surfing the web during your video? Why not add code to pause the video if the page becomes inactive?

title: DELIVER IMAGES OF DELIVERABLES
description: Does your video use professional photos of your deliverables? If not, try adding them.

title: WORK OUT THE WHY
description: Why does someone need your solution? Think of several reasons and then try testing all of them.

title: CHANGE CONTENT OFFERINGS
description: Some people prefer white papers, some like webinars. If you’re offering content in your video, try testing both options.

title: MODIFY A SINGLE BULLET
description: Did you know that modifying a single bullet sometimes increases conversions by as much as 15%? It’s true--try it for yourself and see.

title: PROMOTE CREDIBILITY
description: Although hype can sell, it may not sell as well as facts/statistics/figures. Run tests to determine which works best for your brand.

title: BE PICKY
description: Instead of trying to be all things to all people, why not explicitly state who your solution is for?

title: VARY IT UP WITH VIDEO
description: Some people respond better to video than images. You can test this for yourself by swapping out an image for a video.

title: GIVE IT AWAY
description: Any social media post offering something FREE is bound to be popular. Try adding the word, FREE, to one of your posts and comparing engagement rates to a non-free post.

title: ADD SOME MYSTERY
description: A teasing headline--one that sparks curiosity--is a great way to get your social media followers to read the rest of your copy.

title: GET ODDLY SPECIFIC
description: Oddly specific numbers appeal to prospects. Put one in your headline and see for yourself.

title: USE SOCIAL PROOF
description: Social proof is a great way of indicating your business’ popularity. If you have plenty of followers or customers, say so!

title: TO CURATE OR NOT TO CURATE?
description: Which works best for your brand--curated content, original content, or a combination of both?

title: FIND A NEW MVP
description: Do you highlight over and over again the same MVP (main value proposition)? If so, why not switch things up by using a new MVP?

title: VARY YOUR APPEAL
description: Are your social media followers soft-hearted or more intellectual? Try writing copy to appeal to both types of individuals to see which content gets the best results.

title: MODIFY CONTENT LENGTH
description: What’s the ideal content length--test very short, short, and long to find out.

title: CARRY ON A CONVERSATION
description: Social media giants know that the best posts and tweets are conversational in nature. Rather than being overly serious, aim to carry on a dialogue with your followers.

title: PERCENTAGES ARE POWER-PACKED
description: Percentages are great attention-grabbers. Try incorporating one into your next blog post title.

title: CUT, CUT, AND CUT AGAIN
description: Ruthlessly remove anything you don’t need on the website pages you direct social media followers to. Doing so will speed up page load times, making followers more likely to remain on your site.

title: TANTALIZE ‘EM WITH TOP LISTS
description: Wanna know why there are so many Top 5 and Top 10 lists on the Internet? They work. Try creating your own “top” blog post and see for yourself.

title: ADD CAPTIONS
description: If you’re not doing so already, try adding captions to the images you post on social media. For bonus points, you could even incorporate a CTA into your captions.

title: CREATE CONTENT BLOCKS
description: Content blocks with heat maps allow you to see exactly where blog readership has dropped off.

title: SELECT A SEGMENT
description: Rather than creating the standard broad offer, why not create an offer for a specific group of people? For instance, a shoe store could test a Facebook post mentioning a deal on all sneakers against a deal for running sneakers.

title: JUST ISOLATE IT
description: Facebook posts and tweets tend to be brief in nature. Take advantage of that by isolating just one feature or benefit of your product and creating interesting copy around it.

title: DITCH FACTS FOR STORIES
description: While facts can be persuasive, sometimes stories are more so. Try testing a fact-laden Facebook post against a post that tells a story.

title: TELL A STORY
description: A personal story or review makes for a highly effective persuasion tactic. Try using one in your next Facebook post to see how followers respond.

title: HUMOR HELPS
description: Rather than boring your followers to tears with overly serious social media content, why not incorporate some humor into your posts, tweets, and blogs?

title: REPOSITION SOCIAL BUTTONS
description: Would you like to increase the number of social media followers you have? Try repositioning the social buttons you have on your website so they’re more noticeable.

title: STOP BEING SO SERIOUS
