description: While humor may not work 100% of the time, it really does work often. Try using humor in your tweets, posts, and blogs, and testing them against more serious content.

title: SHOW THE DESIRED OUTCOME
description: Rather than creating Facebook posts that just show your product or people using it, try showing photos of the outcome users will experience if they BUY your product. For example, a home listings site found that by changing their existing photo to one of someone standing next to a “Sold” sign, signups increased by 89%.

title: ADJECTIVES + ADVERBS = AWESOME
description: Strong adjectives and adverbs in a headline can increase clicks.

title: AVERT LOSS
description: Rather than emphasizing gains (“Do this to lose weight”), create a headline around loss aversion (“Do this to avoid gaining weight.”).

title: MANAGE THOSE TAGS
description: Proper tag management will cut down on page load times. Try using Google’s tag manager which combines apps and third-party services into one JavaScript container for faster page loading.

title: LINGER OVER THE RIGHT LENGTH
description: What’s the ideal-sized headline for your blog posts? Test a few different ones and find out.

title: CHANGE PERSONAL PRONOUNS
description: Perspective matters. If you frequently write posts/tweets/blogs using he/she/me/we/you, try using different personal pronouns.

title: THE EYES HAVE IT
description: Want more clicks? Try creating a Facebook post that includes an image of someone staring at your CTA.

title: BE UNPREDICTABLE
description: Irregular punctuation is an attention-grabber. Why. not. try. using. odd. punctuation. in. your. next. tweet?

title: PUT OTHERS FIRST
description: Instead of tooting your own horn in social media posts (“We’re the best,”), put your customers first (“You deserve the best.”).

title: CHANGE DAYS
description: Rather than always posting on Wednesday, for instance, why not try posting on Tuesday or Thursday instead?

title: INCORPORATE POWER WORDS
description: There are some words that always get attention: emergency, new, cheap, and fast for starters. Try using these or other power words in your social media content.

title: ALTER TIME
description: Do you always post or tweet at the same time each day? If your answer is yes, experiment by posting at different times of the day.

title: PREPARE YOUR READERSHIP
description: Social media followers can be scared off by the prospect of a lengthy article. To minimize fears, why not indicate the average reading time for each of your blog posts?

title: BE AUTHENTIC
description: Rather than creating Facebook posts and blogs that use stock photos, try using images of actual people instead.

title: YOU TALKIN’ TO ME?
description: Not sure which tone your brand should use? Try tweeting two days in a row at the same time, using a different tone each day.

title: CHANGE YOUR COLORS
description: Just as with images, you also want to test background colors. Could your blog benefit from a new background color? Test and find out.

title: TEST CTA TEXT
description: By simply changing the text of your CTAs, you could increase conversions. Replace “Learn More” with “Read More” or vice versa.

title: CURIOSITY IS COMPELLING
description: Can you ask a question in the headline of your blog or Facebook post? Yes, you can and should test this popular copywriting tactic.

title: HAVE AN IMAGE SHOWDOWN
description: Images can make all the difference--try testing image A against image B to see which works best.

title: ALLITERATION’S ALRIGHT
description: Alliteration is a sentence where every word begins with the same letter: Apples Are Amazing! Try this tactic in a tweet or Facebook post.

title: DRAW IT OUT
description: Hand-drawn illustrations and mind maps can be particularly compelling in videos. Create 2 versions of your video--one with a map or illustration and one without to see which generates more conversions.

title: REMOVE SUBLINKS
description: If you’re using navigation sublinks, why not try removing them to see how site visitors respond?

title: DITCH NAVIGATION
description: Wanna keep customers hyper-focused on your CTA? Try removing navigation links entirely.

title: DROP IT DOWN
description: You want your navigation to be user-friendly. To this end, try testing drop-down boxes against text links to see which option visitors seem to prefer.

title: GET SNEAKY
description: Most businesses find that the removal of navigation links from checkout pages keeps customers focused on completing their purchases.

title: CHANGE YOUR AXIS
description: Which works best--a horizontal navigation menu or a vertical one? Try both and see.

title: REMOVING SLIDER
description: Home page sliders have the potential to be irritating. Just as they capture a visitor’s interest, they seem to rotate to the next image. Try running a slider vs. no-slider test.

title: TURNING YOUR SECONDARY MENU INTO YOUR CORE MENU WITH DROPDOWNS (PATEL)
description: What would happen if you removed your primary navigation completely and replaced it with your secondary navigation? In cases where the primary navigation is easily overlooked, this modification may improve your overall site engagement.

title: THE ORDER OF ITEMS IN YOUR NAVIGATION
description: Is your order off? Try changing the order of your navigation options to find out.

title: PRICE MATTERS
description: If you’re selling your app, it’s very important to find the right price point for it. How can you know what it should be? Use a landing page to test various prices to see which is most profitable.

title: TRY IN-GAME ADS
description: If you have a gaming app, run tests to discover how in-game ads affect user engagement.

title: SCREENSHOTS SELL
description: Screenshots can make or break an app. Try testing various screenshots to see which one people prefer.

title: TEST PRICE POINTS
description: Your copy probably centers heavily around a main value proposition (MVP). Try changing your MVP to find out how prospects respond.

title: ADD AN AD
description: What’s the impact of adding a small ad to the bottom of your app? Test and find out.

title: YOUR ICON IS EVERYTHING
description: While “everything” may be a strong word, the icon you use for your app is definitely important. Why not try creating a landing page for your app, then testing multiple icons to see which gets the best response?

title: FIND THE PERFECT LENGTH
description: What’s the ideal length for the description of your app? Experiment with multiple lengths to find out.

title: OFFER IN-APP PURCHASES
description: For gaming apps, in-app purchases may be very profitable. Try testing different items you can offer to purchase.

title: MAKE IT EASY (OR HARD)
description: Which is more enjoyable to gamers--an easy game or a hard game? Try testing different levels of difficulty with your gaming app to learn the answer.

title: INCENTIVIZE SOCIAL MEDIA
description: Word-of-mouth is oh-so-important when it comes to mobile app popularity. Try offering various incentives to users for social media sharing.

title: BE PROACTIVE WITH PUSHES
description: When your users have been inactive for awhile, how long should you wait to send them a push notification? Try different lengths of time to find out.

title: TRY OUT TAGLINES
description: Your tagline is a catchphrase or a slogan for your app. Try coming up with 3-4 and then running tests to see which one is most successful.

title: BULLETS ARE BENEFICIAL
description: Is your app description laden with paragraphs? Break those paragraphs into bullet points for maximum effectiveness.

title: RENAME IT
description: If you haven’t released your app yet, now’s the ideal time to perfect its name. Test 3-4 different names on a landing page to see which one generates the most enthusiasm from your visitors.

title: TAKE ON JUST ONE
description: Even one bullet can make a big difference. Try revising just one bullet to see if your conversion rate improves.

title: USE ICONS
description: Could you replace your navigational text with icons? Or what about using a combination of text AND icons? Try both options to see which works best for your brand.

title: USE A DIRECT DESCRIPTION
description: Try testing two different app descriptions: one that says exactly who your app’s designed for and one that doesn’t.

title: USE STRONG WORDS
description: Strong adjectives and adverbs in your app description can increase its appeal. Try using them for yourself to see what impact they have on conversions.
